Cecilia D. is a hardworking woman. She is married to Rogelio, who is a farmer. Their primary activity is agriculture, producing rice and corn. They also plant vegetables in order to make their farm prosper and, aside from that, Cecilia is maintaining a hog raising business. She is requesting additional assistance from Kiva lenders to support the business for her family's needs and her children’s education.

In this regard, she is requesting a loan from Kiva of 7,000 PHP to purchase a supply of hog feed. Her three children are all currently studying, and she hopes to give them a bright future someday through hard work and perseverance.

loans.use: To purchase hog feed

loans.name: Akuwa-Die

texts.en: Akuwa-Die B. is single and has one child. She has no formal education. She sells groceries like Milo (malted milk), milk, gari (couscous-like grain made from grated cassava), sugar and so on at Aboadiwrom near Shama-kedzi. She has been in this business since 2007. Akuwa-Die uses her income to pay fees and utility bills. She will use this loan to buy more groceries to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Akuwa-Die plans to save towards her child’s education.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Taleb

texts.en:
Taleb is a 48 year old man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon. Taleb has owned bakery since 2004. He does “saj”and “mankoucheh”. The “saj” is the metal oven where you do the saj bread and the saj bread is a traditional Lebanese cooking dome used to make Markouk (“thinned”) bread and doughy confections or Mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza, most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Taleb requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw material for his bakery. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time.  
His previous loan helped him improve his bakery. Taleb is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and does good mankoucheh. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw material for his bakery.

loans.name: Oluwakemi

texts.en: Oluwakemi is a trained nurse. She has a chemist shop where she sells medicine and groceries. She is hoping for a loan  of N140, 000 to purchase more medicines and groceries to sell. She is 39 years old and married with 3 children. She says "thank you."

loans.use: To purchase more medicines and groceries to sell

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis A. sells goes to the forest and cuts wood for sale at Abrodzirum near Shama-kedzi.  Francis has junior high school education.  He is married and has four children His wife is a trader. Francis has been selling goes to the forest and cuts wood for sale since 2004. He is responsible for the payment of utility bills and general welfare of his children. His loan will be used to buy more wood to sell as firewood. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to save to reinvest in business.

loans.use: His loan will be used to buy more wood to sell as firewood.

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en: Mathew A. T. is married and has three children. He has junior high school background.  Mathew sells fire wood, goes to the forest cuts old and weak threes and sells them at Brodiwrom near Sham-kedzi, which he has been doing since 2005. His wife is a farmer.  Mathew uses his income to pay school fees and utility bills.  Mathew will use the loan to finance his firewood business by purchasing equipments for to enhance the efficiency of his work. With the new profits from his expanded business, Mathew plans to save to educate his children to a higher educational level.

loans.use: Mathew will use the loan to finance his firewood business by purchasing equipments for to enhance the efficiency of his work.

loans.name: Theresah

texts.en: Theresah D. sells fruits and vegetables in small quantities at Abrodzirum near Shama-kedzi. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a teacher. Theresah has junior high school education. She has been in her business since 2003. She is responsible for paying fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more fruits, vegetables and other food supplies to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards her children's education.

loans.use: To buy fruits, vegetables and other food supplies to sell

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en: Anahit G. was born in 1962 in Sevan. She is married and has 2 children. Her son lives and works in another town, and her daughter lives at home and is jobless. During the last 7 years Anahit has worked as a tailor. Now she has her own business: she sells ladies clothes in a rented shop. She asks for a 200,000 Armenian dram loan to buy autumn and winter clothes for resale.

loans.use: To buy autumn and winter clothes for resale

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes B. is married and has three children. She has received senior high school education. Agnes bakes and sells bread at Abrodzirum near Shama-kedzi, which she has been doing since 2004. Her husband is a trader. Agnes uses her income for payment of fees and for the welfare of her family. Agnes will use this loan to purchase more flour and other ingredients to increase production at her bakery. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agnes plans to save to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase flour and other ingredients for a bakery

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is 23 years old. She started her business by selling silver jewelry in her village. Later, she started into a direct selling business, which she has run for the past 6 years. She earns an income of PHP 4,000 each month. She hopes to increase her income by asking for a loan of PHP 18,000 from Kiva lenders. She remembers starting her business with only PHP 5,000 in initial capital. She just hopes to sustain the good performance of her direct selling business with the support of Kiva loans. 

She is married to Eduarne, an FX driver in Rizal, Antipolo. They have two children, Jed Mark, age  4, and Cyrile, age 2. She lives with five family members in Barangay Nungnungan in Cauayan City. Every week, her husband sends her PHP 3,000 for their daily expenses. She works hard and patiently to gain more income to support her son and daughter.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Khamisa

texts.en:
Khamisa J. lives in Atlabara, which is southwest of Juba. She is a 35-year-old married woman with three children who attend the Buluk Primary School.

Khamisa runs a business in which she sells locally produced alcohol. She is requesting a loan to purchase beans, groundnuts and many others producs to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a restaurant.  

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase beans, groundnuts and others producs to sell

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella is 31 years of age. She is married to Warlito, a company driver. They have raised three children: Leo Jazel, age 9, who is in grade 3; Warlito, Jr., age 7, who is in grade 2; and Prince Noah, who is 1 year old. Their family lives harmoniously in Barangay Nungnungan in Cauayan City, a rural plain area that is three kilometers from the city.
	
Bella raises goats. Sometimes, she also cooks food snacks to sell in their village. Her weekly net income from sales is only around PHP 500, but she also generates an income of PHP 3,500 every 2-3 months from livestock disposal. To maintain her business, Bella wants to borrow PHP 12,000 from Kiva. She wants to be a big help to her husband in providing for their family's needs.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Mansa

texts.en: Mansa E. sells gari; she buys raw cassava and processes it into a dough, then fries it to get it dry. She sells her product at Abrodzirum near Shama-kedzi. Mansa has no formal education. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. Mansa has been selling gari since 2004. She pays the school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more cassava to use as dough for the gari she sells. She hopes to save the new profits from her business to increase her income and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more cassava to use as dough for gari

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn A. manages a general store business in their village at BArangay Nungnungan Cauayan City. She is already 30 years old, she is married to Rexon A. who is a tricycle driver in their place and was also a farmer. They were blessed with 3 children namely; Rex - 11 years old, grade 6, followed by Liezel - 10 years old, grade 5, and Jonh Rex - 3 years of age. She has an adopted child and she is now on her primary level of education. 

	She wanted to request for a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP18, 000 for the improvement of her retailing business that is already 3 years operating. She is earning a weekly income of PHP3, 000 and it is being rolled in the business to further maintain her store to progress. She wanted to gain higher income for her to expand their livelihood into hog raising business also for the future of their children.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
For Irene, who is 25 years old, patience and hard work are both important to becoming successful in life.  She once worked in Kuwait as domestic helper for 5 months. However, she did not become successful there, so she went home for good, and started managing a general store. She is also involved in direct selling. Her ambition to improve both businesses encourages her to request for a loan from Kiva lenders of PHP 10,000. 

She is married to Vic A., a tricycle driver. They have one son, Vincent, age 5 who is a nursery school pupil. Five family members live in their home with her parents. She hopes that her business will grow with the support of the Kiva lenders to give her family a satisfying life.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia sells vegetables. She is manages a stall in her village, Barangay Nungnungan in Cauayan City. She is 47 years old and is married to Felipe E.. She is the mother of two children. Aside from vending, she also raises livestock, but because she earns a daily income from sales, that is her focus. Some of her daily income is also invested in her livestock business to improve her family's living standards.

She wants to borrow PHP 10,000 from Kiva to use as additional business capital to further develop her sales and livestock businesses. She only earns PHP 250 (approximately $5.60 USD) in weekly net income from her business. That is definitely not enough for their family's daily needs. She hopes that Kiva lenders will lend her the amount that she is requesting.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 28 years old. She is the mother of two children. She is married to Jun-Jun T., who works as security guard somewhere in Bulacan. Their two children are Kristine, age 8, who is in grade 3, and John Benedict, age 6, who is in grade 2. They reside peacefully in Barangay Nungnungan in Cauayan City. 

Elizabeth has been managing a food processing business for 3 years. She processes sliced carabao (domesticated water buffalo) meat, from which she generates a weekly net income of PHP 1,500 that they use for their family's basic needs and for the education of their children. She has also been managing a livestock business for almost 8 years and also sometimes sells vegetables and fish in her vending stall. She wants to borrow  PHP 15,000 from Kiva lenders to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna D. was born in 1961 in Dilijan. The city has an amazing nature, but poor working conditions. As a result, eight years ago Susanna and her family were forced to move to Yerevan. They live in a rented apartment and have a small business. Susanna's husband works as a tiler and helps his wife in the family trade.

Susanna rents a space at the food market. In the summer, she sells fruits and fish, and in the winter - lemons. Susanna has two daughters; one of them works in a pharmacological agency, and the other works in the mobile firm Orange. Susanna already has received loans from “Nor Horizon” 13 times. Now she needs 500,000 Armenian dram to buy grapes and peaches for her business.

loans.use: To buy grapes and peaches for her business.

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Mrs. Bella Arbaquez of Barangay Calumangan in Barrio Site, Bago City, Negros Occidental, is a 52-year-old wife and the mother of two children, who is concerned about her family's future. This is the reason why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon.

When she and her husband considered starting a business, his skills and knowledge in electronics made them decide to offer electronic repair services to the townspeople of Bago. The only difficulty they had was that they needed capital to start the business so that they could buy the necessary equipment and tools and have working capital. Joining NWTF-Project Dungganon solved this problem for the couple.

With the business up and running, both Bella and her husband work as partners in running the business, and the arrangement has worked well for their family. It has made them more united, and the business is doing well, earning about PHP 30,000 per month, which provides well for their family's needs, and allows them to set aside some money for the future security of their children.

This is Bella's 14th loan from NWTF. She wants to borrow PHP 19,000 to buy more equipment and tools for their business and also add to their working capital.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional equipment and tools to expand business

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: Rachael sells firewood to her customers. She is 60 years old, married, and has 6 children. She hopes to expand her business. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more firewood to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Judi

texts.en:
Judi A., who is 30 year old, has a business selling bread. She is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil and maize flour to sell. She has four children, one of whom is her brother's son, and they all go to school. Judi is married to a soldier who is a 2 rank man in the Sudanese People's Liberation Army. With the extra profits from her loan, Judi wants to build a shop and stock more goods to sell.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase cooking oil and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: commerce

loans.name: Theophilus

texts.en: Theophilus A. sells firewood at Daboase near Shama Junction. He has no formal education. He is married and has three children. His wife is a waakye seller: she buys rice and beans and cooks them together. Theophilus has been selling firewood since 2009. He is responsible for payment of school fees and utility bills. His loan will be used to buy more firewood to sell. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more firewood

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Eliza is a member of the KDC borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro.She is 22 year old woman she is single.

Eliza has owned a food business selling tomatoes for 1 year, She works 12 hours a day and earns monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzania shillings.


This is Eliza`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania. She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more tomatoes for sale.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Eliza hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes

loans.name: Kaku

texts.en:
Kaku P., a 40-year-old woman living in Atlabara near Nyokuron Cultural Center, is widowed due to the death of her husband from malaria, two years ago. She is the mother of four children who are all attending Buluk Primary School. Kaku sells rice and beans at the market and is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders in order to stock more beans to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Kaku is hoping to open up a shop near her home in the future.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more beans to sell

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mrs. Mildred B., a 28-year-old married woman and the mother of one, is a resident of Prk. Balunggay, Palaka Norte, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental. She says that putting up a business was not easy – especially when they had virtually no money to start it – but she had an intense desire to have her own business and help her husband support their young family. Mildred joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 so that she could have access to start-up capital, even if it was just a small amount.

With the help and support of NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mildred started a sari-sari (general store) where she sells a variety of household commodities. She has slowly expanded her product offerings with subsequent loans, by re-investing some of her profits back into her business. Now, in the addition to the usual stuff sold in sari-sari stores, Mildred also sells frozen food, Ready-to-Wear dresses and offers an electronic loading service for pre-paid mobile phones to her neighbors. This earns her an average income of PHP 18,000 per month.

Mildred plans to use her tenth loan cycle of 20,000 PHP to expand the product offerings in her sari-sari even further, so that with the profits, she can finally make some improvements to her home.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of – not just of a few – but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to realities surpassing their dreams. They have learned to live a life that can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon!

loans.use: To purchase additional goods and invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen M., a 35-year-old woman living in the custom area near the market, is married to a driver who drives a land cruiser in the United Nation Development Program (UNDP). She is the mother of two children. Her business is selling charcoal and she requests a loan to build a charcoal store for better storage, safe from rain.

In the future, Ellen says that if she realises possible profits, she will purchase a lorry that will carry charcoal from the producers to her main store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a charcoal store

loans.name: Yakhya

texts.fr: yakhya S. est un societaire de la caisse de baye laye depuis 2006.il est menuisier ebeniste de profession.mais parallelement il exerce une seconde activite axee sur l'aviculture.il sollicite un credit de cent cinquante mille(150 000)frs pour renforcer la quantite d'aliment de betail a stocker et aussi le nombre de sujets a elever.son objectif est d'ameliorer ses benefices pour mieux faire face a ses charges familliales.

loans.use: aviculture

loans.name: Rossemary

texts.es: Rossemary C. Q., es una señora la cual quedo viuda hace un año atrás y desde entonces mantiene sola a sus 4 hijos, los dos mayores aportan trabajando eventualmente en cualquier trabajo que se les presente, la señora tambien trabaja acomodando algunos viveres y cobra a crédito, ella no saca montos fuertes pero tiene muchas ganas de tener con el tiempo un almacen mucho mas grande.
texts.en:
Rossemary C. Q. became a widow one year ago and since then she alone supports her 4 children. The two adult children contribute by working in whatever job that they find. She also works selling some products on credit. She doesn't earn a lot but she has the desire of having a larger store.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of beer to sell at area festival

loans.name: Las Mariposas Group

texts.es:
El grupo LAS MARIPOSAS esta integrada por once personas mujeres D. la localidad D. Santa Catarina Mechoacan municipio D. S. Pinotepa Nacional Oaxaca., están representadas por la sra. Lucina R. H. fue quien organizó el grupo despues D. investigar D. los tramites a realizar para que su grupo pudiera recibir un credito D. Fundacion Realidad, ya que le habian comentado que muchas personas ya habian recibido un credito y que el tramite no era tan complicado.
Todas son comerciantes, se organizaron D. tal manera que cubrieron todos los requisitos y solicitaron credito a nuestra institución para invertirlo cada una D. ellas en la actividad economica a que se dedican,como es:venta D. pan dulce, venta D. tortillas tostadas, tamales, carne fresca D. puerco, elaboración y venta D. sillas D. madera tejidas a mano con palma real, costura, venta D. abarrotes, venta D. tacos y tostadas, el material que tienen que comprar con el dinero del credito son:harina, leña, maiz,sal,cal hidratada, ganado porcino para la venta D. carne fresca,repollo,palma real, madera,mercancia D. abarrotes,hilos, agujas,picante.
ellas comentan que se sienten contentas D. haber encotrado una institución que les brindará el apoyo que tanto habian buscado ya que hace algunos años no tenian la posibilidad D. obtener un credito porque los bancos pedian muchos requisitos comentaron y hoy en dia van a tener la posibilidad D. mejorar su niviel D. vida D. sus familias a travez D. su trabajo.
esperan que Fundacion Realidad continue beneficiandolas con mas credito a futuro ya que ahora tienen
la esperanza D. abrir un negocio mas como en el caso D. la sra. Lucina R. H. que espera poner una taqueria en el centro D. la comunidad.
texts.en:
The Las Mariposas group is composed of 11 women from the Santa Catarina Mechoacan locality in the municipality of S. Pinotepa Nacional Oaxaca. They are represented by Mrs. Lucina R. H. who organized the group after doing the paperwork so that her group could receive a loan from Fundación Realidad, since many people had commented to her that they had received a loan and the paperwork wasn't so complicated. All of the members organized so that they satisfied all of the requirements and requested a loan from the institution so that each member could invested in the economic activity in which they work, such as selling sweet bread, selling toasted tortillas, tamales, fresh pork, making and selling wooden chairs woven with palm, sewing, selling groceries, selling tacos and tostadas. The materials that they need to buy are flour, firewood, corn, salt, hydrated limestone, pigs for the fresh pork meat, cabbage, palm, wood, groceries, threads, needles, and spices. They remark that they are happy to have found this institution that provides them with the support that they have looked for since several years ago they didn't have the possibility of obtaining a loan because the banks asked for many requirements; now they will have the possibility of improving their quality of life of their families through their work. They hope that Fundación Realidad continues to proviD. them with more loan in the future since they have the hope of opening one more business as in the case of Mrs. Lucina R. H. who would like to set up a taco store in the center of the community.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients and products to sell

loans.name: Pensamientos Group

texts.es:
Elizabeth A. R. tiene 47 años y vive en la localidad llamada Santa C., Valle de Chalco Solidaridad, Estado de México y es miembro activo de la UDE: Pensamientos.

Elizabeth se dedica a la venta de fragancias y cosméticos desde hace aproximadamente 2 años, con la finalidad de irse haciendo de artículos para su hogar a través de regalos por sus ventas, pero ahora tiene otra prioridad.  Hace poco menos de un año su yerno sufrió un grave accidente perdiendo la vida, por tal motivo Elizabeth decide recibir nuevamente a su hija con sus dos nietecitos, para apoyarle dentro de sus posibilidades.

Cuando le comentan sobre Fundación Realidad, ve la posibilidad de  solicitar un crédito integrándose así al grupo, ella cuenta con un poco de mercancía pero en estos momentos necesita recibir un recurso  para hacer que su negocio crezca y de esa manera  incrementar sus ventas, de tal forma  que obtenga  mayores ganancias y así poder cubrir gastos de alimentación para sus nietos; su hija trabaja pero lo que gana no es suficiente para cubrir sus necesidades. Elizabeth agradece el apoyo al  crédito que solicita a través  de Fundación Realidad  para obtener las ganancias necesarias.  
              
Los miembros del grupo son: 
Lourdes P. Venta de cosméticos, Ma. Elena Dámaso Venta de cosméticos, Mirna Socorro Venta de cosméticos, María D. Venta de plantas y servilletas, Ma. Del Socorro  Venta de tapetes, Nelva C. Venta de papelería y tlapalería, Norma Zenón Venta de frutas y legumbres, Ma. Del Rocío Venta de frutas y legumbres, Ma. Isabel Flores Venta de ropa, Reyna S. Venta de carpetas y blusas, Ma. De Lourdes O. Venta de antojitos, Raquel O.  estilista, Gisela P. Venta de ropa, Elizabeth A. Venta de cosméticos, Maricela C. Venta de discos, Concepción González Venta de zapatos, Paulina Ramírez Venta de zapatos, Eva Ramírez Venta de repostería.
texts.en:
Elizabeth A. R. is 47 years old and lives in the Santa C. locality in Valle de Chalco Solidaridad in the state of México and is an active member of group Pensamientos. Elizabeth has worked selling fragrances and cosmetics for approximately 2 years with aim of aquiring items for her home through gifts from her sales, but now she has a different priority. A little less than a year ago her son-in-law suffered a serious accident in which he lost his life, and thus Elizabeth decided to take in her daughter along with her two children to help them as much as possible. When people told her about Fundación Realidad she saw the possibility of requesting a loan, being a member of the communal group. She has little merchandise but she needs funds to grow her business to increase her sales and thus earn higher income to cover food costs for her grandchildren. Elizabeth is thankful for the loan that she requesting through Fundación Realidad to be able to obtain the necessary income. The members of the group are: Lourdes P. selling cosmetics, María Elena Dámaso selling cosmetics, Mirna Socorro selling cosmetics, María D. selling plants and napkins, María Del Socorro selling rugs, Nelva C. selling office supplies and hardware, Norma Zenón Venta selling fruits and vegetables, María Del Rocío selling fruits and vegetables, María Isabel Flores selling clothing, Reyna S. selling carpets and blouses, María De Lourdes O. selling regional delicacies, Raquel O. is a stylist, Gisela P. selling clothing, Elizabeth A. selling cosmetics, Maricela C. selling CDs, Concepción González selling shoes, Paulina Ramírez selling shoes, and Eva Ramírez selling pastries.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics, fragrances, materials for facial treatments to sell

location.town: Valle De Chalco Solidaridad  Estado De Mexico

loans.name: Milenka

texts.es: Milenka D. F., esta separada tiene dos pequeñas hijas, y se dedica a la confeccion de pijamas para hospitales y tambien realiza Guardapolvos para Profesores, ella trabaja sola, durante las mañanas atiende su hogar y por las tardes se dedica a la costura y tambien deja las prendas en distintos hospitales, clínicas y centros médicos de nuestra ciudad. vive en casa de sus padres independiente, ocupando dos habitaciones, una como vivienda y otra como taller de costura.

loans.use: Invertira en la compra de tela

loans.name: Chinita

texts.en:
According to Mrs. Chinita C., a resident of Sitio Magtalisay, Barangay Cervantes, Escalante City, Negros Occidental, it is very hard to raise seven children if you rely solely on just one source of income. With such a large family, it was almost impossible for them to live on just what her husband earned as a fisherman. Many times, her husbands catch was too small to cover even the most basic needs of the family, such as food for the day, much less provide for the education of her children, medicine for when a family member gets sick, and other expenses. 

She joined NWTF-Project Dungganon and went into the fish-selling business to supplement her husband's income and make her children's future more secure, because she knew that if she did not take the initiative, her children's future would be in jeopardy.

So, armed with her first loan from NWTF, she started selling her husband's catch, bought fish from some of the other fishermen, and sold them around the neighborhood and around the town for the next 10 years. This business enables her to earn an additional PHP 3,000 for her family.

Now she hopes to expand her business by using her 9th loan of Php 15,000 as additional capital so that she can buy a bigger volume of fish from the local fishermen to sell to her growing number of loyal clients. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Juan Ubaldo

texts.es:
"El Sr. Juan Ubaldo Q. C., tiene la actividad económica de servicio de transporte urbano de pasajeros radio taxi, vive en casa con sus padres ya que es soltero, actualmente el colabora al  sustento de su familia.
El cliente trabaja con nuestra institución desde el año 2007 en banca de emprendimiento demostrando buen historial crediticio."
texts.en:
Mr. Juan Ubaldo Q. C. works providing public transportation service as a radio taxi driver. He lives in his parents house since he is single and contributes to the supporting his family. He has worked with the lending institution since 2007 demonstrating a good credit history.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of tires and battery for his vehicle

loans.name: Las Palmeras Group

texts.es:
En la comunidad de collantes municipio de Santiago Pinotepa Nacional Oaxaca contamos con un grupo solidario que está integrado por cinco personas mujeres cuatro de ellas son casadas y una es madre soltera todas las integrantes se dedican al comercio que es la actividad economica que predomina en esta zona, cada una de ellas se dedica a vender diferentes productos de manera ambulante en la misma comunidad o en localidades aledañas a collantes,la sra. Maria Teresa M. vende carne fresca de puerco, Maribel D. M. vende ropa y perfumes, Emiliana Velasco D. vende dulces en el interior de una escuela primaria y como su esposo se dedica al cultivo de papaya cuando recojen la cosecha apoya a vender papaya que es cada seis meses aproximadamente,Cira Lidia D. S. compra y vende pescado fresco, Ana Maria D. S. vende pollo fresco destazado.
el tiempo promedio que estas personas tienen realizando esta actividad es de hace 15 años, comentan que decidieron trabajar para apoyar economicamente a sus esposos ya que con el salario que ellos perciben del trabajo del campo en ocasiones no cubre los gastos necesarios de sus familias y mas cuando tienen una persona mas a su cargo como son un nieto u otro familiar que mantener como es el caso de la cliente Cira Lidia D. S. que tiene a su cargo una nieta.
La cliente Maribel Domiguez M. quien es la representante del grupo dice que se entero de los microcreditos que otorga Fundacion Realidad con pocos requisitos, reunio a los demas integrantes y los requisitos y solicitó el credito para que se apoyen en la compra de los productos que ellas comercializán como son compra de carne fresca de puerco, ropa y perfumes, dulces, pescado fresco, carne de pollo fresco destazado asi como los gastos que generan cuando tienen que realizar sus compras y viajan a la ciudad de Pinotepa Nacional ó a el Puerto de acapulco Guerrero.
Las clientes dicen sentirse satisfechos con el apoyo del credito que brinda Fundacion Realidad ya que cuando iniciaron su negocio hace tiempo no tenian acceso al credito porque no cubrian los requisitos que pedían los bancos,  esperan que la institución no pare de brindar este tipo de servicio ya que tienen la esperanza de que ciclo a ciclo su inversion sea cada vez mayor y el bienestar  de sus familias sobretodo de los niños sea cada vez mejor y si es posible algun día contar cada una con un lugar ya establecido para ofrecer sus productos.
texts.en:
This unified group of five people is located in the Collantes community in Santiago Pinotepa Nacional, Oaxaca. Four of the women are married, and one is a single mother. All of the members work in commerce, the predominant economic activity in this region. Each one of them sells different products as street vendors in the same community or in the outskirts of Collantes. Maria Teresa Martiniez sells fresh pork. Maribel Domínguez M. sells clothes and perfume. Emiliana Velasco D. sells sweets inside of an elementary school. Her husband grows papaya. When they collect the harvest she helps to sell papaya, which is approximately every six months. Cira Lidia D. S. buys and sells fresh fish. Ana Maria Domínguez S. sells fresh, butchered chicken. On the average, they have spent 15 years doing these activities. They decided to work to economically help their husbands. Their salaries for sometimes working in the fields do not cover the family’s necessary expenses. This is especially true when they have another person to take care of like a grandchild or other relative to support such as in the case of Cira Lidia D. S., who is raising her granddaughter. Maribel D. M., the group’s representative, found out about the micro loans with few requirements that Fundacion Realidad gives. She got together with the other members. They met the requirements and asked for a loan to help them buy the products that they sell like fresh pork, clothes and perfume, sweets, fresh fish, and fresh butchered chicken. The loan will also help with the expenses generated when they have to makes their purchases and travel to the city of Pinotepa Nacional or El Puerto de Acapulco, Guerrero. These clients say that they feel satisfied with the support from the loan given by the Fundacion Realidad. When they started their businesses a while ago, they did not have access to a loan because they did not meet the requirements of the banks. They hope that the institution does not stop offering this type of service. They hope that, cycle to cycle, its investment will be larger each time. Then the well being of their families, above all, the well being of the children, will be better each time. If possible, some day each one will have an established place to sell their products.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and sell products

loans.name: Warlita

texts.en:
Mrs. Warlita O. is a 53 year-old married woman who has 3 school-age children. She lives in Prk. Malipayon, Bago, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. Before she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mrs. O. used to worry about the future of her children, because she knew that her husband's salary would not be enough to pay for their education and other needs.

After she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, she decided to make use of her cooking skills and set up a "carinderia" or luncheonette in which serves affordable home-cooked meals. Her place soon became a popular eating place for the locals, and for the next 5 years, her business gradually improved through her own efforts and with the help of her subsequent loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, which she always paid back on time. Her luncheonette now nets a monthly profit of approximately PHP 8,000, which is a big help to the family.  


Warlita is now borrowing her 15th loan from NWTF. She wants to borrow Php 19,000 to use as additional capital for her "carinderia." The profits are already budgeted to be reinvested in her business after some have been set aside for the education of her children.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her carinderia business

loans.name: Emma

texts.es: La señora Emma vuelve a trabajar con la institución después de tres años, y en este tiempo no trabajó con otra institución, ella se dedica a la confección de buzos deportivos para niños, está trabajando ahora con el colegio Don Bosco , vive en la casa de sus suegros y su esposo trabaja como entrenador en un club deportivo, tiene dos hijos pequeños, uno ya está en el colegio y el otro es bebé. El crédito será invertido en la compra de tela para la confección ya que tiene pedidos para el colegio.

loans.use: INVERTIRA EN LA COMPRA DE TELA

loans.name: Guido

texts.es: Es un cliente antiguo de banca comunal oriundo del beni , hace muchos años radica en santa cruz  vive  en la casa de su tia; desde hace 5 años se dedica a ofrecer el servicio de mariachi canta para dar serentas , en fiestas, cumpleanos y otros junto con un grupo de compañeros que se dedican a lo mismo. Tiene una hijita de 5 años la cual vive con el. El Sr guido necesita un medio de transporte para poder moverse de su domicilio al lugar de trabajo ya que le contratan a altas horas de la noche y el taxi le sale muy caro , el cuenta con el 50% del dinero y nosotros le financiamos la otra parte
texts.en:
He is an old client of the Oriundo del Beni Community Bank. He has been in Santa Cruz for many years. He lives in his aunt’s house. He has been offering his services to sing Mariachi for five years. He sings together with a group of colleagues to give serenades at parties, birthdays, and others. He has a small five year old daughter who lives with him. He needs a method of transportation to be able to get from his home to the place that he works. They hire him to work until late at night, and taxis are very expensive. He has 50% of the money, and we will finance the other part.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for 50% of a motorcycle

loans.name: Adonai Plus Group

texts.fr:
Chantal Mambweni est dirigeante du groupe « Adonaї Plus », composé de 28 membres solidairement unis pour recevoir des crédits de l’IMF HOPE RDC en vue de développer leurs activités. 
Chantal a comme activité principale,  la vente des fruits et d’habits dans un marché périphérique situé à l’ouest de Kinshasa. Elle a acquit depuis 1990, une expérience solide dans ce domaine et travaille durement avec une bonne gestion afin de réaliser son rêve d’ouvrir un jour un magasin d’habillements. Son souci est aussi d’atteindre l’autosuffisance financière dans son affaire qui lui procure mensuellement un bénéfice de $180. C’est pourquoi elle met à profit tous ses talents et ses relations pour atteindre ces objectifs. Chantal est cliente fidèle de l’IMF HOPE RDC qui a obtenu trois fois les crédits et les a remboursés correctement. Elle compte avec le prochain prêt, renforcer le stock de ses marchandises en achetant des habits à revendre en vue d’accroitre le revenu. Agée de 35 ans, Chantal est célibataire avec un enfant qui va à l’école.
texts.en:
Chantal Mambweni is the director of the group “Adonaї Plus” made up of 28 members firmly united to receive loans from the MFI (micro-finance institution) HOPE RDC in order to develop their businesses.

Chantal’s main business is selling fruit and clothes in a market to the west of Kinshasa. Since 1990 she has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to realise her dream of one day opening a clothes shop. She would also like to achieve financial independence through her business that earns her $180 per month. She works to the best of her abilities and uses her contacts so that she might achieve her goals. Chantal is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having three times obtained and correctly repaid loans. She will increase her stock of products with her next loan by buying clothes and reselling them at a profit. 35 years old, Chantal is single and has one child who goes to school.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Operating a butcher shop in the public market is hard work and involves long hours. To be successful in this business, one has to be committed to wake up way before dawn every day to get the fresh meat from the slaughter house and have it displayed in the market before the first customers arrive.

But this is what Mrs. Dolores M. and her husband do each day to provide a good living for themselves and their 3 children. Dolores is 52 years old and a resident of Sitio Kahilwayan, Brgy. Gargato, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. By being her husband's helpmate in the business, she is ensuring that her children will be well provided for and she and her husband will have a nest egg in their old age.

Dolores and her husband are shown in the accompanying picture proudly posing with the chest freezers where they keep meat they do not sell for the day so that it stays fresh and can still be sold the following day.

Dolores joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could have access to additional capital for her business. She has been a good payer, as she has slowly increased her income capacity with each new loan. Now her business nets a monthly income of PHP 14,000, enough to satisfy the needs of her family.

Dolores plans to use her 14th loan, this one for Php 30,000, to expand her business even further and to use as additional working capital for her butcher stand.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: As additional capital for meat stand

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Mrs. Marissa G. is from Punta Tagda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental.  She is 43 years old and married with 4 adult children. She started her buy-and-sell business in 1998 with her first loan of PHP 3,000 from NWRF. 

Later, she and her husband decided that they could increase their income potential if they had their own fishing boat, so she and her husband pooled their capital and bought a small fishing boat. They sell most of the day's catch in the local market and they also make salted dried fish, which they sell to a select clientele. 

Now, Marissa is planning to borrow PHP 19,500 to expand her fish business. She will also use the profits to have their house repaired and make a few home improvements.

About NWTF:  
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon

loans.use: House Repair

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Chris has done what many people only dream of -- he has started working full-time combining two of his passions, kids and football! A former professional football player, Chris had the idea of organizing a kids' football league for many years. The idea came to him when he was coaching his youngest son's team. Chris has a good eye for football talent and wanted to help local kids. Finally, in 2008, he assembled of team of volunteers and went for it!

One of Chris's goals was to be able to provide opportunities for kids who were not able to join football leagues because of financial burden. In his first league, he put four teams together and involved his small community in Idaho by letting them sponsor those who couldn't pay to join the league themselves. Lately, his biggest challenge in tough economic times has been continuing to find funding to expand the league.

By googling "minority business loan," Chris found out about ACCION USA on the Internet. In the past, he had used his personal credit card to pay for league-related expenses, which conveniently allowed him to access cash immediately, but had an interest rate that was unsustainable for larger loans. 

Chris will use this loan to pay for new uniforms, which he says will help build team pride and attract more team members, and to pay for next season's league fees in advance at a discount. Chris hopes he can dedicate himself fully to coaching the team once the business grows to a point where it can sustain his family. He dreams of taking his team to the highest levels of minor league football, perhaps even entering the professional arena one day.

loans.use: League fees and new team uniforms

loans.name: Angel

texts.en:
Angel immigrated to the United States seven years ago and today he is a proud business owner. Three years ago when he felt unfilled in his retail job, Angel decided to open his own electronics business.  He started with very little capital, making it tough to grow his business at first.  When Angel looks back on his first year in business, he remembers the endless amount of work involved and is grateful for where his business is today. Angel’s business has seen much growth and so has his family. He is married with two children ages two and six. Even though business is doing well, Angel explains that things are still tight, especially because of the current recession. No matter what, he says opening his own business was the right decision both personally and professionally.  Self-employment and serving his clients has given him a strong sense of honor while creating a legacy for his children.  Angel looks forward with determination as he grows a healthy business.

Angel started his electronics wholesale business in May 2006, because he wanted to go into business for himself. To start his business, he used credit cards and a loan from family and friends, but he is happy to have found ACCION USA because they offer him credit that is much more affordable and dependable. 

He says his greatest success has been importing electronics equipment from other countries, like China. He will use part of this loan to purchase 100 cell phones from China. It's important to increase his stock in cutting-edge items that his customers demand. One of his biggest challenges is keeping customers coming back because he has the highest quality electronics.

loans.use: Wholesale electronics stock

loans.name: Perpetua

texts.en:
Mrs. Perpetua P. is 53 years old, married and blessed with 5 children. Her family are residents of Tabao Baybay, Prk. Malipayon, San Enrique, Negros Occidental. She dreams of providing a proper education for her children, supporting the family's needs and providing them with a better future. This is Mrs. P.'s main concern, because  she knows that if she relies only on her husband's income, all of her dreams would come to naught, because his income is just too small to sustain the needs of her fairly large family. 

Because of her strong determination to fulfill her dreams, she thought of ways to earn more income. To have access to the much-needed capital to start her business, Perpetua joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, and started selling gasoline in her community. Their place is relatively far from the nearest gasoline station, and there is a demand for gasoline because of the many motorcycles and tricycles (motorcycle with a side-car for passengers) that ply the roads of their community. For 10 years, Perpetua has been fairly successful in this business and it earns her about PHP 4,000 per month.

This will be Mrs. P.'s 14th loan from NWTF. She wants to borrow Php 20,000 to use as additional working capital so that she can expand her gasoline retailing business.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To invest in expanding business

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is married and has two sons. She runs a small business in her hometown of Kherson. Ludmila sells household items in the busy central marketplace. She has been in this trade for 5 years. Ludmila believes that the success of her business is due to disciplined and responsible management tactics as well as friendly customer service and ability to listen to her customers. Currently, she has 50,000 Grivnyas invested in business. Her net monthly profit amounts to 2,000 Grivnyas. 

Ludmila is seeking a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to increase her turnover capital. She is hoping to increase assorted merchandise and continue investing generated income into further development of her small enterprise. Ludmila has promptly repaid 4 previous loans without any delinquencies.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Ferrari Group

texts.en:
Laila M., age 34 is married with one son of two years.  She has a grocery store which she started since 2006.   She works from 9am to10pm daily and she is able to earn a monthly profit of about $.113.

This will be Laila’s 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase on her business, bought chairs, empty crates and has paid the loans back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to increase on business by buying a blender to start selling juice, is going to stat selling water whole sale and bites as well.

Laila will share this loan with her loan group, Ferrari which totals 19 members.  These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Laila  is second from left front row.

loans.use: To increase on business by buying a blender and start selling juice,water  whole sale and start selling bites.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.es:
La señora Adelaida R. tiene ya más de quince años dedicándose a la venta de ropa usada y nueva esté negocio es la fuente de ingreso para su familia ya que tiene dos hijos adolescentes que quiere darles un estudio profesional. 
Esta solicitando un préstamo para comprar más mercancía ya que tiene poca y quiere invertir en ropa de invierno ya que viene la temporada y quiere estar preparada con suficiente mercancía, y así tendrá más ingreso a su familia y a al negocio, que con las ganancias planea pagar el crédito.
texts.en:
Adelaida R. has been selling used and new clothing for over 15 years. This business is the source of income for her family. She has two adolescent children. She would like to give them the education to become professionals. She is asking for a loan to buy more merchandise because she does not have much. She wants to buy winter clothes because the season is approaching. She wants to be prepared with sufficient merchandise. That way she will have more income for her family and her business. She plans to pay the loan with that income.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Don De Dieu Plus Group

texts.fr:
Etina B. 32 ans, est présidente du groupe dénommé « Don de Dieu Plus », composé de 24 membres solidairement unis pour bénéficier des prêts octroyés par l’IMF HOPE RDC dans le but de développer leurs affaires. 
Etina est entrée dans le monde de micro-entreprise depuis 2004. Elle gère sa propre boutique et vend aussi des habits. Elle est cliente fidèle qui a reçu quatre fois les crédits de HOPE RDC et les a totalement remboursés. Le prochain prêt de Kiva lui servira à renforcer le stock en achetant des habits à revendre pour augmenter le bénéfice. Son ambition est d’ouvrir un jour, un grand restaurant à Kinshasa. La rigueur et le sérieux dans le travail sont les éléments qui font prospérer son activité. Etina est mariée et mère de deux enfants âgés de 7 et 16 ans. Tous deux vont à l’école.

loans.use: acheter le stock d'habits à revendre pour accroitre le bénéfice

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Félix Ignacio

texts.es:
El señor Félix Ignacio G. y su esposa la señora Thelma Paulina Torres son un matrimonio joven y tiene un hijo pequeño ha quien le quieren dar lo mejor.
Es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo para poder la diferencia de una vivienda por medio de un crédito gubernamental, ya que actual mente están vivienda en casa de su suegra pero el desea darle su propia casa ha su familia. 
Félix Ignacio es empleado de una tienda de joyería fina  en el departamento de evaluador de oro, este es el ingreso que el tiene para su familia y con el cual una parte será para el pago del crédito.
texts.en:
Señor Félix Ignacio G. and his wife, Señora Thelma Paulina Torres, are a young married couple with one small boy to whom they want to give the best. This is why Félix is requesting a loan as an alternative to government subsidized housing. He wants to give his family a home of their own since they are currently living with his mother-in-law. Félix works in a fine jewelry store as a gold appraiser. This job gives him the income to provide for his family, and part of it will go toward the repayment of his loan.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Downpayment on a house

loans.name: Bebie

texts.en:
Bebie G., a 49-year old married woman with one child, is a dedicated woman who is determined to improve the lives of her family and provide them with a better future. Bebie and her family are residents of Burgos St., Hinigaran, Negros Occidental, and she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to reach her dream.

Mrs. G. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to borrow capital to start a fresh egg distribution business with her husband. To add to their income potential, they later also started selling balut (a fertilized egg that contains a nearly-developed embryo) and salted duck eggs, which are popular with the locals. With the help of her husband, Bebie has been quite successful in her business and a very good member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for the past 9 years, which is why the staff of NWTF-Project Dungganon in Hinigaran where she belongs chose her as Entrepreneur of the Year during the Branch Foundation Day.

For her 24th loan, she is borrowing Php 29,500  to expand her business even further.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: As additional capital for her business

loans.name: Fernando

texts.es:
A la vivienda del señor Fernando B. le está haciendo falta pintarla principalmente y desea cambiar la fachada de la misma. Pretende realizar algunos maceteron de concreto algunas molduras que hagan ver una casa más bonita.
En este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para realizar esos cambios a su vivienda, es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo.
El planea pagar el crédito con los ingresos de su trabajo de técnico de eléctrico de la comisión de agua potable (municipio), es el ingreso que tiene para su familia, ya que tiene dos hijos adolescentes quienes están estudiando. 
El señor B. ya ha tenido un crédito con FVP el cual pagó puntualmente.
La persona que aparece en la fotografía es su esposa la señora Lucina Martínez ella nos atendió el día que se realizó la visita a la vivienda de la familia B..
texts.en:
The home of Mr. Fernando Baez is in need of painting and exterior finish work, but at this time he lacks the money necessary to repair his home. This is why he is requesting a loan for the exterior finishes. He plans to pay the credit with the income from his job as an electric technician at a potable water company. This is also the income he has for his family, which includes two teenagers who are students. Mr. Baez has already had a credit with FVP which he pays punctually. The person who appears in the photo is his wife Mrs. Lucina Martinez, who was the person that assisted us the day the visit was made to the home of the Baez family.

Translated from Spanish by Joseph Tobin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pintar la vivienda y realizar una fachada para su casa.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys A. sells electrical parts and auto parts near Shama Junction. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a carpenter. Gladys received junior high school education. She has been selling electrical parts since 2003. Gladys helps pay the school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to expand her business by buying more electrical parts for resale. She hopes to save the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy electrical parts

loans.name: Cedron Group

texts.es: El grupo CEDRON esta integrado por 3 personas que son familiares pero que viven en distintas zonas, la señora Emiliana es la cliente mas antigua, trabajaba con credito individual desD. el año 2006, ahora paso a integrar el grupo con sus hijas Reyna y Juana T. quienes eran integrantes del grupo el año 2008. Estas señoras viven en Coqueni y doña Emiliana en la Comunidad Uni (poblado muy alejado). Siempre trabajaron bien , sus pagos los realizaron en forma puntual.
texts.en:
The CEDRON group is maD. up of 3 people who are family members but live in different areas. Ms. Emiliana is the longest standing client and has worked with individual credit since 2006. She has gone on to form the group with her daughters Reyna and Juana T. who have been part of the group since 2008. These ladies live in Coqueni and Ms. Emiliana lives in the Uni Community (a very distant settlement). They have always worked well, and their payments were maD. in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Joseph Tobin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising capital

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel A. is married and has four children. He has received a senior high school education.  Samuel sells Milo (a milk beverage), milk, coffee, cocoa powder and so on in Aboso near shama junction, which he has done since 2007. His wife is a fishmonger who buys fish from the seashore, then smokes and sells them.  

Samuel uses his income to pay school fees and utility bills. Samuel will use the loan to purchase more groceries to fill his shop. With the new profits from his expanded business, Samuel plans to save to educate his children.

loans.use: Samuel will use the loan to purchase more groceries to fill his shop

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina T. sells poultry feed and brown feed at Aboso near Shama Junction, which she has done since 1999. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a poultry farmer. She has junior high school education. Faustina uses her income to help pay fees and utility bills. Faustina will use this loan to purchase more poultry feed to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Faustina plans to save for her children’s future.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry feed

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es:
La señora Rosa María F. tiene ya más de cuatro años dedicándose a vender ropa usada y nueva, esté negocio es la fuente de ingreso de su familia ya que es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos pequeños a quienes les quiere dar lo mejor. Doña Rosa María ha tenido ya cuatro créditos con FVP los cuales ha pagado puntualmente.
Está solicitando un préstamo para comprar un comprar un vehiculo ya que el que tenia ya no sirve, y lo necesita para estar trasportando la mercancía ha diferentes partes de la ciudad de Nuevo Laredo. Y si su negocio tendrá más  ingreso para su familia y con el cual una parte será para pagar el préstamo

loans.use: Comprar un vehiculo para transportar su mercancía

loans.name: Jhaqueline Victoria

texts.es: La Sra. Jhaqueline H. trabajo como Banco de Emprendimiento "Perlas de Bella Vista" dos secuencias el año 2007 al 2008, ahora solicita un credito individual para invertir en su negocio que tiene un año de antigüedad. Tiene una hija en edad escolar y el esposo es transportista de la la linea de radio taxis, en el dia tambien se dedica a la venta de articulos para el hogar como electrodomesticos y su negocio principal lo realiza en horas de la noche, venta pollo frito. Por su historial y referencias de sus vecinos la señora es una persona responsable.
texts.en:
Jhaqueline Haunca has worked with Perlas de Bella Vista Communal Bank for two years in a row -- 2007, through 2008 -- and now is requesting an individual loan to invest in her business which is one year old. She has a school-age daughter, and a husband who works at a taxi transportation business and, during the day, also sells things like household appliances. Her primary business, which she does in the evening, is selling fried chicken. Her history and references from neighbors describe a responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Hannah Lily, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing things to make fried chicken

loans.name: Ines

texts.es: La Sra. Ines Q., es cliente nueva en la institución, fué recomendada por un cliente antiguo muy conocido y puntual. Se dedica a dos labores, una es la venta de ropa tradicional de "cholita" que vende de manera ambulante en su zona, los principales productos que vende son sombreros y mantas típicas,  tambien tiene un trabajo de medio tiempo en un restaurante de comida rapida en su calle, en este lugar se dedica a la elaboración de hamburguesas, hot dogs y pollos broasted. Por su actividad muy pequeña necesita de incremento de capital por lo que solicita este credito, que será invertido en la compra de ropa típica de "cholita" para su venta ambulante en su zona. El esposo de la señora trabaja de albañil, tienen dos hijos pequeños. La señora Ines comenzó a trabajar desde sus 18 años (a la fecha tiene 24) y segun la informacion adquirida por sus vecinos, la señora Ines es una persona muy responsable.
texts.en:
Ines Q. is a new client who has been recommended by an existing, reliable client. She has two jobs. She sells traditional Bolivian "cholita" clothing on foot in her neighborhood, mainly hats and traditional shawls. She also works part-time at a fast food restaurant on her street, where she prepares hamburgers, hot dogs and broasted chicken. Her business is very small, so she needs more investment capital, which is why she is requesting this loan. She plans to use the money to buy traditional "cholita" clothing to sell on foot in her area. Ines's husband is a builder, and they have two young children together. Ines has been working since she was 18 years old (she is currently 24), and according to her neighbors she is a very responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Staff

loans.use: Purchase of traditional women's hats

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es: La señora Lidia se dedica a la venta de pescado frito y caldo de pescado conocido como "wallake", está ya bastante tiempo en esta actividad, vive en la casa de su mamá y colabora también con los gastos de la casa, tiene un pequeño hijo que matiene ella sola, en su casa vive con sus hermanos quienes se apoyan y se ayudan mutuamente, es una cliente muy puntual y muy responsable, el crédito lo inevrtirá en la compra de papa, chuño (papa desidratada) y oca (tuberculo andino) por mayor, ya que su mamá está viajando a su pueblo y traerá estos insumos a menor precio y en mayor cantidad.
texts.en:
Lidia sells fried fish and a fish stew known as "wallake". She has been involved in this activity for a long time now. She lives in her mother's house and contributes to the household expenses. She has a small son for whom she is the sole source of support. She also shares her home with her siblings, all of whom help each other out. She is a very punctual and responsible client. She will use this loan to purchase potatoes, dehydrated potato, and oca ( which is a type of andean tuber) wholesale taking advantage of her mother's trip to her home town where these raw materials are available at lower prices and greater quantity.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to prepare fish-based meals

loans.name: Teodora

texts.es: La señora Teodora es una cliente antigua D. la institución, tiene su anaquel D. dulces y golosinas en la Av. Camacho, zona central D. la ciudad D. La Paz. Vive en su casa con sus hijos que ya son independientes y le ayuda con los gastos D. casa. Es muy cariñosa con sus nietos y sigue velando por el bienestar D. sus hijos. Es una cliente muy responsable y muy puntual, el crédito será invertido en la compra D. chocolates "El Ceibo", que son producidos aqui en Bolivia, son muy agradables, y también comprará otras golosinas para el anaquel.

loans.use: INVERTIRA EN LA COMPRA CHOCOLATES

loans.name: Elizabeth Wendy

texts.es: La Sra. Elizabeth Wendy O. E., tiene como atividad la realizacion de artezanias, (pintado de manteles, elaboracion de cotillones y trabajos con goma eva) aumentando de esta manera su ingresos que tiene como profesora de escuela, actualmente su nucleo familiar esta compuesto por ella y su hija de 4 años, por el momento por su situacion se enuentra viviendo en casa de sus padres.
texts.en:
Elizabeth Wendy O. E. is a craftsperson specializing in painting tablecloths, making gift bags and making vinyl objects which she sells to increase her income earned as a teacher. Her family currently consists of herself and her 4-year-old daughter. Due to her economic situation she is currently living with her parents.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase raw materials (fabric, glue, appliques) and tools.

loans.name: Filomena

texts.es: La señora Filomena es una cliente antigua D. la institución, muy responsable y puntual, tiene su tienda en su casa propia, su esposo trabaja con su movilidad ,sus hijos ya son independientes, su tienda ya tiene varios años y es muy conocida por la zona, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra D. cerveza, ya que los fines semana tiene pedidos D. este producto, por las fiestas que hay en la zona.
texts.en:
Filomena has been a client of the institution for a long time now; she is very responsible and punctual. She runs a grocery store from her home. Her husband works and her children are no longer dependent on their parents for support. Her store has been in operation for several years now and is very well known in the area. She will use the funds to purchase beer to have on stock since this is a highly requested item especially on the week-end due to the number of parties in the area.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beer.

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.es: La señora Felicidad, es un cliente relativamente nueva,  trabajo mas de cuatro secuencias  con la institución y demostro responsabilidad y puntualidad, al momento de la visita demostro que tiene buena actitud y buen caracter el cliente, la Señora Felicidad se dedica a la venta de articulos de ferreteria, ella tiene su puesto fijo en la feria de la 16 de julio,  los dias jueves y domingo, tambien distribuye de forma ambulante en la diferentes ferias de El Alto, la señora compra los articulos de ferreteria por mayor y ella los vende al detalle de esa forma le sale un margen de ganancia. Su esposo Martin Mamani Matha se dedica a la albañileria,los trabajos que su esposos realiza son eventuales, la pareja actualmente tiene dos hijos sus dos hijos estan en colegio. La Sra. Felicidad invertira el préstamo en la compra articulos de ferreteria por mayor.
texts.en:
Felicidad is a relatively new member, having worked with the institution for four cycles; she has shown punctuality and responsibility and during the home visit was seen to have a positive attitude and a good client profile. Felicidad sells hardware supplies from a stall at the July 16th fair on Thursdays and Sundays. The rest of the time she travels to various other fairs in El Alto. She buys her supplies wholesale and resells them retail thereby increasing her profits. Her husband, Martin Mamani Matha, is a laborer who works occasionally. They currently have tho children who are in school. She will use these funds to purchase hardware supplies at wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wholesale hardware supplies.

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.es: La sra. Candelaria se dedica a al venta de papa y verduras en una tienda ubicada en la zona de Pampahasi, su esposo se dedica a la venta de cd´s y dvd´s, en la tienda del lado, ambos trabajan y se colaboran mutuamente para los gastos de la casa y para el estudio de sus hijos. Ella tiene pedidos por cantidad para las pastelerías-heladerías del centro de la ciudad, ya es muy conocida en este rubro. Es una cliente que retorna después de un año. El crédito será invertido en la compra de papas por carga ya que los pedidos que tiene aumentaron.

loans.use: INVERTIRA EN COMPRA DE PAPA AL POR MAYOR

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.es: El señor Marcelino y su esposa la señora María Juana viven en la zona Villa Salomé. La señor Marcelino vive en la zona desde que era pequeño. Ellos viven junto a su joven hijo y uno de los más grandes anhelos de ellos es lograr que él sea profesional. Don Marcelino tiene un minibus del Sindicato Miraflores. Él es chofer hace quince años por lo que tiene buen conocimiento de la cuidad. El crédito será invertido en la cancelación del cambio de la movilidad en su sindicato, ya que para ingresar tienen que pagar su acción.

loans.use: PAGO POR CAMBIO DE MOVILIDAD AL SINDICATO

loans.name: Silvia Petra

texts.es:
"La Srta. Silvia Petra G. A., tiene como actividad  la venta de jugo de fruta, realizando jugos vitamínicos y otros en la zona central de La Paz, es una cliente joven y dinámica, actualmente vive en casa de su hermana ya que es soltera.
La cliente fue recomendada por su hermana quien viene trabajando con nuestra institución de una manera responsable."

loans.use: Incremento de Capital

loans.name: Vandyeck

texts.en: Vandyeck T. is married and has nine dependants. He has received senior high school education.  Vandyeck sells soft drinks in whole sale at Bosodwina near shama junction, which he has been doing since 2004. His wife is a trader.  Vandyeck uses his income to pay bills and school fees.  Vandyeck will use the loan to buy more soft drinks in bulk to sell. With the new profits from his expanded business, Vandyeck plans to save towards building a house.

loans.use: Vandyeck will use the loan to buy more soft drinks in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Progreso Group

texts.es:
El Banco comunal Progreso está formado por 10 clientes, pertenecen a la Zona de Pampahasi Alto;las socias se dedican a la venta de Cd`s, Edredones, Pijamas, Abarrotes, Maqueteria, Cosméticos Durante su permanencia en Emprender, que son 8 ciclos se reestructuro en un 80% de las socias.
Helen B. Álvarez, Es la líder y presidenta del banco desde hace 2 ciclos teniendo en cuenta que el banco ya tiene como antigüedad 8 ciclos, la socia se dedica a la venta de pijamas. 
En su banco comunal ha aprendido a ser una líder responsable con sus compañeras, exigente con sus cuotas de sus compañeras a la hora de pago, amigable, alegre. con el préstamo que se le ha otorgado a podido aumentar su capital y aportar de esa forma con ingresos para su familia.
Angélica Rogelia C. P.,  es la secretaria del banco, se dedica al arte de la maqueteria (tejido de ropa a mano) actualmente se encuentra trabajando como ayudante asalariada debido a que no contaba con capital para emprender su propio negocio, sin embargo ahora con el préstamo que se le dará  ella podrá comprar  materia prima para  iniciar su propio negocio.

Maitte Silvia D. A. Socia bastante dinámica, alegre, es la tesorera del banco; es una de las socias que se preocupa por las demás, exigente a la hora de pagar las cuotas, durante su permanencia en el banco siempre se encuentra animando a sus compañeras, a seguir adelante, actualmente se dedica a la venta de cosméticos, el crédito solicitado, lo requiere para la compra de mercadería.
La señora Maitte tiene dos hijos pequeños, sin embargo esta no es una limitante para ella ya que sale a comercializar sus productos en compañía de sus niños debido a que no tiene con quien dejarlos mientras va ha trabajar.

loans.use: Incremento de capital

loans.name: Trinidad Aleyda

texts.es:
"La Sra. Trinidad Aleida C., tiene como actividad la atención en su  salón de peluquería para damas el cual esta ubicado en la zona de Sopocachi,cerca de nuestras oficinas, es una cliente nueva, actualmente vive en casa de sus padres junto a su pequeño hijo, siendo ella la que genera ingresos para su familia.
El destino de dicho crédito será para la compra de nuevo instrumento de peluquería y para el mejoramiento de su vivienda ."

loans.use: Invertirá el préstamo en la compra de instrumentos de peluqueria y arreglo de su vivienda.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice C. sells fruits such as bananas, apples, grapes and so on at Bosodwina near Shama Junction. She has been in business since 2005. Alice is married and has two children. Her husband is a surveyor. She has senior high school education. Alice uses her income to help with the payment of bills and school fees. Alice will use this loan to purchase more fruits to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Alice plans to improve her plantation farm.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Ama Tsiewaa is married and has three children. She has junior high school.  Ama sells frozen fish,she  buys fish form the cold store to resale at Abrodzirum near sham-kedzi, which she has been doing  since  200. Her husband is a farmer.  Ama use to support in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Ama will use the loan to purchase more of the frozen fish to sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to save towards building a house to live in with the family.

loans.use: Ama will use the loan to purchase more of the frozen fish to sale.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama A. sells accessories like traditional earrings, pomade and cosmetics at Abrodzirum near Shama-Kedzi. She is a widow and has one child. Ama has no formal education. She has been in her business since 1984. Ama uses her income to pay fees and settle bills. Ama will use this loan to buy more earrings and other jewelry to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to save towards the education of her grandchildren.

loans.use: To buy more earrings,  jewelry and cosmetics

loans.name: Ines

texts.es: Inés tiene 36 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora que vive con sus hijos; Fernando de 11 y Alexander de 12 años de edad. Desde hace 6 años se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir en el taller que tiene en su casa. Ella vive sola con sus hijos y esto le demandad mucho tiempo, ya que están en edad escolar y necesitan mucho de su apoyo y consejo. Es por ello que un trabajo en su casa le pareció mucho más adecuado, pero no significa que sea más fácil, pues necesita de gran precisión a la hora de elaborar los pedidos, que son en gran cantidad y muchas veces no puede abastecerse sola para acaparar con todo, es por ello que tiene que pedir ayuda. Pero Inés ha sabido sobrellevar este tipo de obstáculos porque sabe que si sigue trabajando con mucho empeño podrá tener en el futuro un taller más grande y así brindarle un futuro mejor a su familia. Es su cuarto préstamo con MFP, ella es muy puntual y responsable con todos sus pagos, al igual que lo fue en su grupo, ahora solicita un préstamo individual.
