Ella nos manifiesta su complacencia por pertenecer muchos años a un grupo de mujeres que le ha ayudado a superar dificultades que en algún momento tuvo que pasar pero que ahora los enfrenta con mucha fortaleza.

loans.use: Comprará sacos de pescados secos, en diferentes especies.

loans.name: Lauristela

texts.es: La señora Lauristela, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora D. la Paz”, Distrito D. Tarapoto, Provincia D. San Martin, Departamento D. San Martín. Está Casada, tiene 56 años.Su fuerza  y anhelo D. sacar adelante a sus hijos, le motivaron a emprender su propio negocio D. venta D. abarrotes, que se encuentra ubicado en su misma casa, un ambiente muy bien acondicionado para atender a sus clientes. Las ganancias que genera a diario le ayuda a mejorar el ingreso económico D. su familia. DesD. su  inicio a la fecha ha ido ganando clientes y hoy en la actualidad tiene clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su negocio a comprar porque ella  tiene todo los productos  que el ama D. casa necesita y es quien personalmente les atienD.  con la amabilidad y carisma que le caracteriza. Con este préstamo D. S/ 1,200.00, comprará sacos D. arroz y azúcar, fideos, sal y aceite en paquetes, leche y conservas D. pescado en cajas y en variedad D. marcas, huevos en javas y artículos D. higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Lauristela, se siente muy bien, para continuar trabajando y se prepara día a día para asumir los retos  que la vida le presenta y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades D. desarrollarse en el medio donD. se desenvuelven.

loans.use: Comprará abarrotes, para aumentar sus productos.

loans.name: Sulmira

texts.es: La señora Sulmira, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora de la Paz”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 46 años, 03 hijos, 02 que aun dependen de ella.Su carácter emprendedor y el amor a su familia le motivaron a iniciar su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes que poco a poco fue aumentando y ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad, haciéndose muy conocida y querida entre sus clientes.  En la actualidad tiene sus clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su bodega a comprar donde cuenta con todo lo que el ama de casa necesita y es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con alegría y entusiasmo. Con el préstamo de S/ 1,500.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Anhela convertir su bodega en un minimarket y manifiesta que lo va a hacer realidad  porque es una mujer que cuando se propone algo lo cumple.

loans.use: Comprará abarrotes, para aumentar sus productos.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.es: La señora Rosalía, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora de la Paz”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 51 años y 03 hijos, 01 que aun dependen de ella.Lleva 12 años dedicándose a la venta de Abarrotes. Su fuerza  y anhelo de sacar adelante a sus hijos y seguir generando sus propios ingresos le motivaron a emprender su negocio, muy bien establecido que se encuentra ubicado en su misma casa en un ambiente acondicionado para atender a sus clientes. Las ganancias que genera a diario, la ayuda al ingreso económico  en su familia. Desde su  inicio a la fecha ha ido ganando clientes y hoy en la actualidad tiene clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su casa a comprar y es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza.Con este préstamo de S/. 2,500.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Rosalía, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando, y prepararse para hacer frente a las adversidades de la vida  y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse en el medio donde se desenvuelven.

loans.use: Invertirá comprando, abarrotes para aumentar su stock

loans.name: Nimia

texts.es: La señora Nimia, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora de la Paz”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 54 años, 02 hijos, 01 que aun dependen de ella.Su fuerza  y anhelo de sacar adelante a sus hijos, le motivaron a emprender su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes, se encuentra ubicada en un local muy bien acondicionado, en su misma casa, para atender a sus clientes.Las ganancias que genera ayuda al ingreso económico de su familia, desde su  inicio a la fecha ha ido ganando clientes y hoy en la actualidad tiene clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su puesto a comprar porque ella  tiene todo los productos  que el ama de casa necesita y es quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza.Con este préstamo de S/ 1,800.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Nimia, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando y prepararse día a día a lo que la vida se le presenta y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse en el medio donde se desenvuelven.
texts.en:
Sra. Nimia is a member of the Communal Bank “Nuestra Señora de la Paz” (Our Lady of Peace), which is located in the District of Tarapoto, San Martín Province, Department of San Martín. She is 54 years old, married, and has 2 children (1 is still a dependent). Her strength and desire for her children to succeed are what motivated her to start her own grocery store. She manages her business out of her home, which is well equipped for attending to her customers. The revenues generated from her business have enabled her to support her family. She has been gaining customers since she started her business and now she has a regular clientele who come to her store to shop because it has all the products a housewife would need. Nimia personally welcomes her customers with her charismatic personality.

With her loan of 1800 soles she will buy sacks of rice and sugar, packaged noodles, milk, various brands of canned fish, crates of eggs, and personal hygiene products. This will help her continue providing good service to her customers.

Nimia has the strength to continue working and she prepares herself every day for what life presents. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping women like her and providing them with opportunities to develop in the communities where they operate.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase groceries to restock her store

loans.name: Isidora

texts.es: La señora Isidora, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora de la Paz”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martin, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 52 años y 04 hijos, 01 que aun depende de ella.Isidora, lleva ya varios años dedicándose a la venta de relojes, decidió sacar un prestamo en Manuela Ramos y con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00, implemento su negocio y poco a poco fue haciéndose conocida.En la Actualidad continua con el mismo negocio, ubicada en el Mercado Central de su Ciudad, lleva 09 años, trabajando en el negocio y ahora ya tiene una clientela fija que realizan sus compras y como también va ofreciendo a sus amigos, familiares y vecinos, le va muy bien y mensualmente genera sus propios ingresos y con el carisma que tiene, obtiene buenas ganancias. Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000.00, comprará relojes de todas las marcas y modelos, para damas, caballeros y niños, así como correas, pilas para relojes y lentes de sol, para complementar sus productos.Isidora, se siente muy contenta por lo logrado, feliz por que en su negocio le va muy bien. Esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla en iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Sra. Isidora is a member of the Communal Bank “Nuestra Señora de la Paz” (Our Lady of Peace), which is located in the District of Tarapoto, San Martin Province, Department of San Martin. She is 52 years old, in a common law marriage, and has 4 children (1 is still a dependent). She has been selling watches for several years. With her first loan of 300 soles, she launched her business and gradually became known in the neighborhood. Sra. Isidora has been running her business for the past 9 years from the central market of the city. She has a steady clientele which includes friends, relatives and neighbors. With her charismatic personality, her business continues to do very well and generate monthly profits. With her loan of 2000 soles, she will buy watches of different brands and models for men, women and children. She also plans to purchase wristbands, watch batteries, and sunglasses to complement her product line. Isidora is very happy with what she has accomplished and that her business is doing very well. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business as well as other women who want to grow as entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase watches, wristbands, batteries & sunglasses

loans.name: Doliveth

texts.es: La señora Doliveth, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres en Acción”, Distrito de Picota, Provincia Picota, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 45 años y es madre 03 hijos, que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.Doliveth, se inicio con S/. 400.00 esto le sirvió para implementar su pequeño salón de belleza, ubicada en su misma casa, un local bien acondicionado, para atender a sus clientes.Nos cuenta que hoy en día le va muy bien, ya que es conocida por sus amigos y vecinos, realiza diferentes tipos de tintes, peinados y cortes, tanto para damas, caballeros y niños.En la actualidad ofrece el mismo servicio  y con el préstamo de  S/ 500.00, comprará sus materiales de trabajo como: laca en frascos, tintes de cabello en diferentes colores, oxigenta, talcos, shampos y cremas de pelo.Es ella quien toma las decisiones en los gastos y ganancias de su negocio. En lo personal,  se siente una Mujer independiente, decidida y más segura, responsable con el pago de sus cuotas. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle el apoyo, para iniciarme con su actual negocio.
texts.en:
Doliveth belongs to the "Mujeres en Acción" (Women in Action) Village Bank, in the District and Province of Picota, Department of San Martín. She's 45, single, and the mother of three children, all of whom are still in school and dependent on her. She started out with 400 soles, which allowed her to open her small beauty salon in her own house, which is well-equipped to serve her clients. She tells us that nowadays things are going very nicely since she is known by her friends and neighbors, and she offers a variety of colors, cuts, and styles for men, women, and kids. Doliveth is continuing with her business, and she plans to use her loan for 500 soles to buy supplies, including bottles of hairspray, a variety of hair colorants, peroxide, talc, shampoos, and crémes. She's the one who makes the decisions regarding her business's expenses and profits. Personally, Doliveth feels like an independent woman, determined, more secure, and responsible for making her payments. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for offering her the support to start up her current business.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies: bottles of hairspray, and hair colorants.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es: La señora Ruth Marín, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres en Acción - Picota”, Distrito de Picota, Provincia Picota, Departamento de San Martín. Es Viuda, tiene 56 años, 05 hijos, 01 que aun dependen de ella.Su fuerza  y anhelo de sacar adelante a sus hijos, le motivaron a emprender su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes, se encuentra ubicada en su misma casa, un puesto bien acondicionado para atender a sus clientes. Las ganancias que genera ayuda al ingreso económico de su familia. Desde su  inicio a la fecha ha ido ganando clientes y hoy en la actualidad tiene clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su puesto a comprar porque ella  tiene todo los productos  que el ama de casa necesita y es quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza.Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Ruth, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando, y prepararse día a día a lo que la vida se le presenta y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse en el medio donde se desenvuelven.
texts.en:
Sra. Ruth Marín is a member of the Communal Bank “Mujeres en Acción – Picota” (Women in Action – Picota), which is located in the District of Picota, Picota Province, Department of San Martín. She is 54 years old, widowed, and has 5 children of whom 1 is still dependent. Her strength and desire for her children to succeed are what motivated her to start her own grocery store. She manages her business out of her home, which is well equipped for attending to her customers. The revenues generated from her business have enabled her to support her family. She has been gaining customers since she started her business and now she has a regular clientele who come to her store to shop because it has all the products a housewife would need. Ruth personally welcomes her customers with her charismatic personality.

With her loan of 1000 soles she will buy sacks of rice and sugar, packaged noodles, milk, various brands of canned fish, crates of eggs, and personal hygiene products. This will help her continue providing good service to her customers.

Ruth has the strength to continue working and she prepares herself every day for what life presents. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping women like her and providing them with opportunities to develop in the communities where they operate.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more groceries

loans.name: Tessy Katty

texts.es: La señora Tessy Katty, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres en Acción - Picota”,  Distrito de Picota, Provincia Picota, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 22 años y 01 hija que aun dependen de ella.Tessy Katty, es una mujer que se siente capaz de cumplir sus metas, por lo que decidió implementar su propio negocio  con el apoyo de su pareja., poco a poco fue ahorrando y juntando su propio capital y con el prestamo de Manuela Ramos implemento su negocio de venta de abarrotes, ubicada en un local alquilado, muy bien acondicionado y hoy ya tiene mucha experiencia en este tipo de actividad  y es muy conocida y querida entre sus clientes.  En la actualidad tiene una clientela ya fidelizada que a diario acude a su tienda a comprar donde cuenta con todo lo necesario y es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Tessy Katty, hoy en día se siente una mujer muy realizada, con más ganas de seguir adelante y hacer realidad sus sueños. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por ayudarla en iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarial.
texts.en:
Tessy Katty belongs to the Mujeres en Acción – Picota Community Bank, Picota district, Picota province, San Martín department. She is 22, in a common law marriage, and has one daughter who is still dependent upon her. Tessy Katty is a woman who feels capable of meeting her goals. Therefore, she decided to start her own business with help from her significant other. Little by little she was saving and gathering her own money. With the loan from Manuela Ramos she started her business of selling groceries. It is in a rented, well set up location. She now has a lot of experience in this type of work. She is well known and liked by her customers. She currently has loyal customers who come to her store to shop. They can find everything they need, and she personally waits on them with her characteristic charisma. With this loan for 1,000 PEN she will buy sacks of rice and sugar, packages of noodles, milk, boxes of different brands of canned fish, crates of eggs, and personal hygiene articles in order to keep giving her customers good attention. Tessy Katty now feels like a fulfilled woman with the desire to get ahead and make her dreams a reality. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business and also for helping so many women who want to grow as entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries

loans.name: Claribel

texts.es: La señora Claribel, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres en Acción - Picota”, Distrito D. Picota, Provincia D. Picota, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 52 años y 01 hijo, ya independiente.Claribel, lleva 20 años dedicándose al Alquiler D. Habitaciones, decidió sacar un préstamo en Manuela Ramos y con su primer crédito D. S/. 300.00, siguió implemetanto y mejorando sus habitaciones. En la Actualidad continua con el mismo negocio y con este préstamo D. S/. 3,000.00, comprará cemento en bolsas, enchufes y pintura, para remodelar y dar una buena atención a sus clientes.Claribel, se siente muy contenta por lo logrado, feliz por que en su negocio le va muy bien. Esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla en iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Claribel belongs to the Mujeres en Acción – Picota Community Bank, Picota district, Picota province, San Martín department. She is 52, married, and has one independent child. Claribel has spent 20 years renting rooms. She decided to get a loan from Manuela Ramos. With her first loan for 300 PEN she set up and improved her rooms. She currently continues with the same business. With this loan for 3,000 PEN she will buy bags of cement, electrical sockets, and paint in order to give good attention to her customers. Claribel is very pleased with what she has accomplished. She is happy that her business is going very well. She is grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business and for helping so many other women who want to grow as entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction materials

loans.name: Rita Maribel

texts.es: La señora Rita Maribel, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres en Acción - Picota”, Distrito de Picota, Provincia Picota, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 37 años y es madre 02 hijos, que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.Rita Maribel, se inicio con S/. 300.00 esto le sirvió para implementar su pequeño salón de belleza, ubicada en un local alquilado muy bien acondicionado, para atender a sus clientes.Nos cuenta que hoy en día le va muy bien, ya que es conocida por sus amigos y vecinos, realiza diferentes tipos de tintes, peinados y cortes, tanto para damas, caballeros y niños.En la actualidad ofrece el mismo servicio  y con el préstamo de  S/ 500.00, comprará sus materiales de trabajo como: laca en frascos, tintes de cabello en diferentes colores, oxigenta, talcos, shampos y cremas de pelo.Se siente una Mujer independiente, decidida y más segura, responsable con el pago de sus cuotas. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle el apoyo, para iniciarme con su actual negocio.
texts.en:
Rita Maribel belongs to the Mujeres en Acción – Picota Community Bank, Picota district, Picota province, San Martín department. She is 37, single, and has two children who are still dependent upon her and go to school. Rita Maribel started with a loan for 300 PEN, which she used to start her small beauty salon. It is in a rented location, which is well equpped to wait on her customers. It is going very well now. She is well known by her friends and neighbors. She does different types of dyes, hair styling, and cuts for women, men, and children. She currently does the same work. With this loan for 500 PEN she will buy work materials like bottles of hairspray, a variety of hair colorants, peroxide, talc, shampoos, and hair creams. She feels like an independent woman, determined, more secure, and responsible for making her payments. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for offering her the support to start up her current business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Materials she uses for hair styling

loans.name: Nilda Zulema

texts.es: La señora Nilda Zulema, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres en Acción - Picota”, Distrito de Picota, Provincia Picota, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 43 años, 05 hijos, 03 que aun dependen de ella.Lleva 03 años dedicándose a la venta de abarrotes, gracias a las ganancias obtenidas  logró implementar mas su propio negocio, se encuentra ubicada en su misma casa en su misma.Con el primer préstamo que recibió logro implementar mejor su bodega, hoy sus vecinos y amigos ya le conocen y tiene mucha acogida, sus ventas le salen a pedir de boca y piensa seguir adelante y prosperar con otros negocios.Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, comprará abarrotes como: sacos de arroz y azúcar, paquetes de leches y aceites; gaseosas en paquetes de diferentes sabores y tamaños e insumos para la limpieza del hogar e higiene personal. Así de esta manera mantener a sus clientes satisfechos y contentos.Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida. Así mismo agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle apoyo a ella y a  demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante.
texts.en:
Nilda Zulema belongs to the Mujeres en Acción – Picota Community Bank, Picota district, Picota province, San Martín department. She is 43, married, and has five children. Three of the children are still dependent upon her. She has been selling groceries for three years. Thanks to the earnings she received, she was able to expand her business, which is located in her house. With the first loan she received, she was able to improve her store. Now her friends and neighbors know her, and she is well received. Her sales have been going smoothly, and she plans to keep going forward and prosper with other businesses. With this loan for 1,000 PEN she will buy groceries like sacks of rice and sugar, packages of milk and oil, different flavors and sized packages of soft drinks, household cleaning supplies, and personal hygiene items. This way she will keep her customers happy and satisfied. She is very satisfied with the work she does. She believes it is worth the sacrifice to make your dreams come true and meet the goals you have set out for your life. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping her and other women who want to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: La señora Rosa, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres en Acción - Picota”, Distrito de Picota, Provincia de Picota, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 37 años y es madre de 04 hijos, 01 que esta bajo su poder y estudia. Ante la necesidad de aportar al ingreso económico del hogar, motivada por ella misma, emprendió su pequeño negocio de venta de panes, con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00, obteniendo muy buenos resultados, por los precios cómodos y la buena atención al cliente. Posteriormente, agrego a su negocio la venta de abarrotes, ubicada en su misma casa. En la actualidad continua con sus dos negocios, donde sus principales clientes son los vecinos de su barrio.Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000.00, comprará  más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en kilos, huevos en javas,  insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, gaseosas en paquetes, golosinas  y otros productos para mantener contenta a su clientela. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá, en la compra de insumos, para preparar sus panes.Hoy se siente muy feliz de la labor y servicio que brinda y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, por apoyar a personas como ella que quieren trabajar y salir adelante, espera que sigan así por mucho tiempo y ayuden a muchas familias y mujeres emprendedoras.
texts.en:
Rosa belongs to the Mujeres en Acción – Picota Community Bank, Picota district, Picota province, San Martín department. She is 37, married, and has four children. One child is still dependent and goes to school. Out of the need to contribute to the household income, and being self motivated, she started a small business selling bread with her first loan for 300 PEN. She got good results because of the reasonable prices and good customer service. Later, she added grocery sales to her business, which is located in her house. She currently continues with the two businesses. Her main customers are her neighbors. With this loan for 2,000 PEN she will buy more products to stock her business like kilos of rice and sugar, crates of eggs, personal hygiene items, household cleaners, packages of soft drinks, sweets, and other products to keep her customers happy. She will use part of the money to buy supplies to prepare her breads. She is very happy about the work and service offered. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping people like her who want to work and get ahead. She hopes they continue this way for a long time and that they help many families and enterprising women.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries and supplies to make her breads

loans.name: Mr. Savuth Ung Group Loan

texts.en:
Mr. Savuth U. is leader of the group which consist of four people and they live in Chrouy Pisei village in Takeo province.

Mr. Savuth U. is a car repairer in the local village. Since this business is going well, he decided to ask for a loan to buy more car accessories for his customers and he hopes to make more income for his family.

Mr. Savuth U. is 47 years old and the father of six children, four of whom are employed in different jobs and the others two are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more car accessories for his customers

loans.name: Mrs. Pouy Shum Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of twenty-four people, is located in Daem Rues village in Kandal province. They will each use the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Pouy S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who is also a Khmer noodle seller in the local village. Since this business is going wE., she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients to make Khmer noodles to sE. to earn more profit. She is a widow with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the youngest one is a laborer in a rice mill.

Two members in this village bank have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any princiP. on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the princiP. whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for making Khmer noodles

loans.name: Mrs. Chanthoeun Chum Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
22-people who all live in Daem Rues village in Kandal province is made up the village bank and all the members will use the loan which they obtained in different purposes. Mrs. Chanthoeun C. us a village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns 1.08-hectar to cultivate rice. In rice farming, she faces a small problem because her field is infertile soil so it is affected to her rice crop. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Preap Sambath, helps her in the farming. Mrs. Chanthoeun C. is a mother of a child who is attending the local school. 

Seven members in this village bank loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en: Mary Grace P. is from the village of Capucao, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children. Mary Grace owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting cassava for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over fourteen years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month. Mary Grace joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Han

texts.en:
Mr. Han N. is a villager in Preak Russey village in Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice for a living. On his farm he now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to buy rice seed to cultivate. So he decided to ask for a loan to buy seed and he will use the rest of the loan to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow the field.

Mr. Han N. is the father of five children who are all attending the local school. His wife, Mrs. Pin Yeoun, helps him with farming. His wife is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow the field

loans.name: Mrs. So Un Hem Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
Mrs. So Un H. is the village bank president of sixteen people who all live in Preak Thmey village in Kandal province. Mrs. So Un H. is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Nob Moeurn, is a Khmer Traditional Healer in the local village. They have a child who is a construction worker. While his work place is far from house and he mostly spend much money on transportation, Mrs. So Un H. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her child to travel to work in order to reduce her expenses. 

Eight members in this village bank loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows tH. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her child to travel to work in order to reduce her expenses.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann A. is the 41-year-old mother of five children who range in age from 1 to 19. Mary Ann’s husband is a laborer, and to help augment his sporadic income she put up a small variety store in their village as a business twelve years ago.

Mary Ann’s membership in ASHI at that time enabled her to have access to credit for business capital. All throughout her membership, she has shown a very good performance in loan repayment, in attendance during weekly center meetings, and in her business. From selling little variety of commodities when her business started, her store now sells almost all necessary commodities that people in their village need for their everyday living. The profit she has in her business is increasing.Thus she is able to continuously request a loan from ASHI every time she repays her previous loan.

Though Mary Ann’s business earns profits well, they are yet insufficient to finance the education of her children, especially her two eldest who are in college, at the same time as reinvesting some portion into her business. Therefore, Mary Ann requests a larger loan amount to be able to sustain and finance the growth of her business and to be able to increase her profit further.

Once all of her children have finished college, Mary Ann wishes to build a concrete house for her family and to grow her business into a big grocery store in their village.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Mak

texts.en:
Mak N. is 45-year-old married woman and mother. She lives with other family members in her own small family home in Siem Reap Province.

Mak N. owns a piece of land on which she grows different kinds of crops and raises a few pigs as well. She will sell to buyers every two or three months when her produce or her pigs have matured.

Mak N. is married with four children, one of whom is married and the others are single. Her husband works in construction to earn a living.

Mak N. requests a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed, as well as to hire a laborer to help her on the farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed, as well as to hire a laborer to help her on the farm

loans.name: Mrs. Phalla An Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
This village bank loA. group, which consists of fifteen people, is located in Boeng Krum Leu village in Kandal province and all the members will use the loA. for different purposes.

Mrs. Phalla A. is the village bank president. She is 26 years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Lim Sambo, is a driver.

Mrs. Phalla A. is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she grows vegetables. She is also a vegetable seller in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more vegetables to resell to earn more income. 

Five members in this group have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loA. until the very end of the loA. term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita Y. is Johnny’s 38-year-old wife. She is a mother of two children who range in age from one to nine. She is a member of ASHI since 2004 and has been running a variety store for a business seven years now. Years before she has an access to credit through ASHI, growing a business is yet a vision for Nenita. She has no sources for business capital then to be able to sustain the business together with the expenses her family incurs everyday. Her husband’s income being a laborer is sporadic thus Nenita’s profit and some portion of business capital were used for family expenses. Thereafter, through a loan Nenita had from ASHI, she has had grow her business making it to profit bigger. From a variety store business, Nenita has able to put up another business which is mini restaurant and videoke (video with karaoke sing a-long) bar in their village out of her profits. Her costumers in the restaurant and videoke bar are also her costumers in her variety store. Her videoke bar and restaurant are people means of relaxation and family bonding. In here, family members sing together and eat together.
Nenita is requesting for a larger amount of loan to improve her variety store business to be able to meet the demands of her costumers.  She wants to make sure that once her costumers are inside the premises of her business, their needs are met.

loans.use: Will be used for an additional capital for growing her variety store business.

loans.name: Mrs. Chantrea Khorn Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
Twelve people who all live in Boeng Krum Leu village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Chantrea K. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members, who will all use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Chantrea K. is 35 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows vegetables.

Mrs. Chantrea K.’s husband, Mr. Chim Phal, is a fisherman. Now he needs a machine to connect to his boat for fishing. Thus, Mrs. Chantrea K. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose.

Four members in this group have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a machine to connect to her husband's boat for fishing

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia G. is a fish vendor and has been in her business for the past twenty-five years. She and her fisherman husband, Delfin, are partners not only in life but also in business.

Growing a business without access to credit was hard for Cecilia since both she and her husband have no other business for a source of income. This became worse when her two children had to go to college.

Wanting to sustain the education of her children in college, Cecilia had to make her business profitable by growing it. Thus, she decided to join ASHI to be able to have access to additional capital.

From then on, Cecilia’s business started to grow until the time has come when Cecilia now has to request a larger amount of capital. She has to increase the volume of the various fish she buys and sells in her fish stall in the municipality’s public market.

Someday, Cecilia wishes that, out of the profit her business makes, she will be able to purchase a vehicle to be used in her business for selling and buying a larger volume of fish in far off places.

Cecilia is so happy for having loans for her business because her profits have enabled her to send her two children to college. Her eldest is a commerce graduate while the second child is a college undergraduate. Whatever life they will be having in the future, Cecilia will be very happy to turn over her business to her children someday.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Mith

texts.en:
Mith L., 27, lives in Pursat province, Cambodia, where she has owned a plot of land since 2000. She grows rice crops, which she plants twice a year.

Mith L. is a good mother to her two school-aged children. Her husband sells wood carvings that he makes using wood from the forest.

In view of the fact that rice growing is Mith L.'s main source of income to sustain her famiL.’s living conditions, and in order to help her meet the hard physical labor demanded by farming work, Mith L. is applying for a loan to buy a cow to use for plowing the fields and also to raise its offspring.

loans.use: To buy a cow to use for plowing the fields and also to raise its offspring

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca S. is a 62-year-old widow and a mother of two children, ages 19 and 21. Ever since she joined ASHI eleven years ago, she has been selling rice and dried fish. Francisca also has another venture: selling balut, a boiled egg with a three-day-old chick inside. Balut sells every night, as it’s a huge Filipino favorite. Francisca profits nicely in her balut business, a great help in augmenting her rice and dried fish income.

Before her children entered college, Francisca sustained her enterprises through loans available through ASHI with all profits going to her children’s support. Now, however, with the greater expenses of college, Francisca must work harder to increase her profits, especially since she is widowed and with no other source of income. She has determined that once her children have finished their studies, she will save her income for both family emergencies and her businesses.

For now, she is requesting from ASHI a loan for additional business capital so she can buy larger volumes of rice and dried fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy more rice and dried fish to sell and to sustain her balut venture

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao S., 53, is a single father who has seven children: five are teenagers and two are married and live independently. Most of his children are employed. Since early 2000, Sao S. has been earning a living by retailing charcoal and wood for carving in the village. He buys in bulk, from wholesale suppliers, and typically generates an income of US$3 each day from his sales to contribute to the family’s daily living conditions. Sao S. will use his first loan to purchase a motorbike. This will reduce the cost of hiring a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann O., 30, is a low-income citizen who is requesting a loan of US$100. He will use the funds to buy more fertilizers to fatten his rice crop that is not growing well. He and his wife are local cultivators. Besides their farm, Vann O. is also going to work in constructiO., for a profit. This couple now lives with their five school-aged children in Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers to fatten his rice crop.

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en: S. is 51 years old married man and father. He has seven children; six of whom depend on his care, while the other one is married and lives away from family home. S. and his son are currently working as local chefs; they always hired by neighbors to cook meals for their wedding parties and their other ceremonies. His wife’s name is Hong, age 50, who sells porridge and raises poultry from home, and who appears in the picture over. S. is applying for a loan as capital to buy more poultries to raise. He proposes to use the rest of loan to operate selling cooking supplies out of his home.

loans.use: To buy more poultries to raise

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Even before Helen A., 54 years old, became a member of ASHI in 2008, rice production (rice farming) was already her business. When she joined ASHI, she started a hog fattening (pig raising) business while she was waiting for her rice crop to reach the harvesting stage. Through hog fattening Helen also felt that she could have a source of capital for her rice production business. She would use the funds from selling her pigs towards the rice farming. She would also be able to run her rice production business independently from the allowance given to her by her two single sons.

Helen has four children and a farmer husband. Her two eldest children have their own families now, while her third son has been working abroad for a year. Her youngest son works in a factory in Manila. Helen and her farmer husband work their farm and hire farm laborers only during planting season. Every planting season, Helen worries about the expenses that her farm requires to produce rice. She doesn’t want to oblige her children to provide for her financial needs. For this reason, she wants to expand her hog fattening business. In the hog fattening business, profit can be as much as double the amount of capital after only four months of raising pigs. The more pigs she has to sell, the more Helen will profit. With the loan Helen is presently requesting, she will buy more pigs and she will also finance the planting of rice.

When Helen’s business becomes stable, she would like to help her children to send their children to school until graduating from college.

loans.use: Will be used to finance her growing hog fattening (pig raising) business and rice production (rice farming) business.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn V., 20 years old, joined ASHI early in 2009 to be able to have access to credit for starting a business. A variety store was the first business she thought she knew how to run and could augment the income her husband is earning from being a cook of one eatery in their town. However, Jocelyn was not able to control people crediting from her store, therefore, her business towards the end of her loan lost its capital.  Through the financial support of her husband, she was able to pay back her loan on time and have another business, eight months ago, which is hog fattening. 
With the hog fattening business, Jocelyn profits as much double the amount of her capital after only four months of raising the pig. For the second time with ASHI, Jocelyn is requesting a loan which she will use for financing her hog fattening (pig raising) business. The more pigs she will raise and sell, the more profit she will be making. As they don’t have children yet, she wants to prepare financially for a time when they will have children.

loans.use: Will be used to finance her hog fattening (pig raising) business.

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.en:
Tomasa D. is 62 years old and has been raising pigs and cattle for a business since the time she joined ASHI in 1997. She has been able to have access to credit for business capital. Profits she makes from her livestock raising business augments the sporadic income of her laborer husband. She has been able to send her three children to school and had hoped that all of them would graduate from college. However, her two elder sons chose not to pursue their education. Now, they are laborers and are helping Tomasa in managing her business. 
Tomasa’s determination for growing her business became more intense because she wants to secure the future of her two children despite their low attainment in education. She wants her youngest daughter to finish her course in nursing. Tomasa is requesting a larger loan to be able to purchase more pigs and cattle to be raised in their backyard surrounded by verdant fields of grass and rice.

loans.use: Will be used for an additional capital for growing her livestock raising business.

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth V., 38, is married to Herson, a government employee. They have three children who range in age from 4 to 15. Her eldest two children are in high school. Maribeth became a member of ASHI in 1998 and since then has been able to access credit for business development. She then started a variety store. Initially income generated from the business was insufficient to sustain her family's needs. However, her business grew because of the loans she continuously received from ASHI. She also acquired a space in the municipality’s public market to sell goods.

After Maribeth gave birth to her youngest child, she decided to temporarily close her business as there was no one to look after her children at home and attend to their needs, especially to the needs of her youngest. Being without business for over a year, Maribeth realized that her husband’s income alone is insufficient to finance the growing expenses of their family, including her children's educational expenses. Therefore, Maribeth requested a loan from ASHI to re-start her business. After three years, she was able to grow her business again. She now requests for a larger amount of loan as additional capital to expand her business. This is mainly to prepare for the upcoming college education of her two elder children and also for the education of her youngest child.

loans.use: Additional capital to grow her variety store business

loans.name: Peou

texts.en: Peou S. is an older man, 55 years old and father. Since 1980, he has been working as a chief of social affair in province. He is married to Sokhom, age 51, who stays at home to raise a few poultries and look after for the children as well. The older couple was married years ago and blessed with three children; one of whom is married. Two of their children are employed: their first daughter is a poultry breeder and second son is a Cambodia guide and a taxi driver. Peou S.’s son would like to operate his taxi service at the airport but he is required to pay a service fee. Therefore Peou S. would like a loan to allow his son to pay the airport service fee so he can find customers at the airport which will help him attract more tourists and earn extra income.

loans.use: To pay the airport service fee

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario Abarola, 47, lives in a village near the seashore along with her husband, 49, and three children. Most families in their village depend on fishing and fish selling as the main source of income. Rosario’s family is one of them. Rosario’s husband and eldest son are fishermen, while Rosario is into financing business. The loans that she requests from ASHI are not only used to finance her husband and son’s fishing business but also other fishermen’s business in the village. She profits by getting a share of fish from the fishermen whom she finances. The sharing depends on how much money Rosaria finances to the fishermen.

Rosario sells her share of fish together with her husband and son’s fish in the market. Aside from her financing and fish-selling business, she also has an eatery in their village. After selling fish in the morning, she manages her eatery for the rest of the day. At the end of the day, she happily counts the money she has made and looks forward to the next day. She requests a larger amount of loan for her growing business. Out of the profit her business makes, Rosario wants to finance her youngest child’s education until graduation as her two eldest children are unemployed because of lack of education.

loans.use: Additional capital for financing and fish-selling business

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
40-year-old Vilma F. is a mother of three children who range in age from 13 to 18 years. Her fisherman husband is her partner in the business and in raising their children. Vilma’s fish selling business started to grow six years ago. Initially, loans she requests from ASHI when she became a member in 1996 were used to grow her husband’s fishing business.  In 2003, she used her loan in buying fish from other fishermen in their village in addition to her husband’s fish for selling. Since then, she continuously finances the said business. She realized big profit she makes out of it thus, she would like to requests for a larger amount of loan this time to be able to grow her business further. She likes to purchase bigger volume of fish to sell in her stall in the market.
Once her business had grown through loans she requests from ASHI, she will be able to generate bigger profit making her able to send her three children to school until they graduate from college. Vilma also wished to renovate their house for the security of her entire family especially her children.

loans.use: Will be used as an additional capital to grow her fish selling business.

loans.name: Pat

texts.en: Pat P. was born in 1959; he is a married man and blessed with four children. Two of them are married and others are single and work in construction. He is currently a domestic fisherman, while his wife's name is Kim Bath, 56, and she has built a pigpen behind her house where she raises many pigs to earn a living. Because the pig-raising business is a very profitable for family, Pat P. would like a loan of US$ 300 in order to buy additional feed and piglets to raise for sale during the period when pork is commanding the highest price. Note: Pat P.'s wife appears in the photo above.

loans.use: To buy additional feed and piglets to raise

loans.name: Choub

texts.en: S. is shown in the picture over. She is age 27 and lives with family members in the Province of Kompong Tom, since 1979. She currently generates income by raising pigs from her home. She sells out her pigs from pigpen to her buyers when the pigs are matured during three or four months after she begin feeding. As another source of family income comes from her husband's work, selling firewood and fishing. S. is applying for a loan as capital to purchase more pigs to raise. S. has blessed with two kids who attend school.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to raise

loans.name: Asel's Group

texts.en: Asel is the mother of two children and is the leader of this group. At the age of thirty-five she has quite an active family: her daughter works in a big supermarket in the capital, whereas her son goes to college in another city. Her husband is a self-employed taxi-driver. Asel sells vegetables. Her present occupation greatly differs from her previous one, as she used to work as the head of a city firefighting department. There, a friend of hers advised her to get engaged in a trade, since the salaries were, roughly speaking, humble. This “career” change of hers has brought a lot of positive changes into her life. It is not only that she has an opportunity to deal with a lot more people, but also it has allowed her and her husband to save sufficient funds to buy a two-room flat. Asel needs a loan to purchase vegetables: tomatoes, cabbages, peppers, etc. With the return, she is going to buy an automatic washing machine. Her future business plans are to buy a van and to open a greengrocer’s shop. Asel has three partners: Elmira, Gulzana and Gerindi: Elmira, 37, is a widow and the mother of four children. She provides for her family by engaging in farming. She grows clover for cattle and sunflower seeds for producing sunflower oil. She needs a loan to buy a milk cow. Gulzana, 32, has a small family consisting of her, her husband, a six-year old daughter and a four-year old son. To make a living she sells milk and trades in sheep. She received this affection for animals from her parents-in-law. Besides that, she works part-time in a worsted factory. She needs a loan to purchase sheep for breeding and resale. Gerindi, 57, is divorced. She has raised two daughters who work and live separately. Gerindi works as the main specialist in a rayon emergencies department. She needs a loan to connect to the heating main. She plans to repair her house and make it more comfortable. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en:
Thorn N. is a 36-year-old mother of two, and raising a pig is a main part of her daily routine. Other than a daily profit from pig raising, she relies on her husband's business of driving a motor taxi, and fishing in Tunle Sap Lake.

The family includes two children, and one of them is enrolled in primary school. The family's living environment is not comfortable, due to the frequent collapses of their house. Thorn N. would like a loan to repair and decorate her old house.

loans.use: Repair and decorate her old house

loans.name: Delma

texts.en:
Delma G. is a single, 52-year-old woman from the village of Palilan, Jimenez, in the province of Misamis Occidental, Philippines. To make a living, Delma owns and operates a business in the food sector selling fish. Her main source of income comes primarily from buying and selling fish in the local community. Delma has been involved in this business for over 20 years, and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Delma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation, and ability to engage in business activities. Delma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell.

Delma is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be invested in the expansion of her business. This will be Delma's third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Invest in business expansion

loans.name: Chhengkea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhengkea H., 46, and her husband, Mr. Lieng Hun, 44, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometres from Phnom Penh City.  They married in 1990 and have four children, two sons and two daughters. One of the sons assists his father in the business and the others are in local schools.

Chhengkea has been raising pigs for over 10 years. In addition, she is a silk weaver as well. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for more than three years. She has requested a loan from Kiva through Maxima one time already. She is now requesting her second loan of $800 in order to add to her own money to build a staircase for her house.

loans.use: To build a staircase for her house.

loans.name: Bunnarith

texts.en:
Mr. Bunnarith H., age 39, and his wife, Mrs. Sokmoeun Yoy, age 32, were married in 1994. They have two sons, both of them attending school, and one young daughter. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Bunnarith has been driving a motor remoque taxi for nearly three years. He carries goods and people from his village to Phnom Penh and back. A remoque is a motorbike with a trailer at the back. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. In the past, she used to be a garment factory worker. 

Unluckily, his motorbike breaks down which has upset his business. His main source of income is only from his business. Therefore, he is applying for a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase a new motorbike to replace the old one.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike to replace his old one

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Leng S., 52, buys cows from people who live in rural areas, fattening and then selling them for profit. He normally makes around $6 per day to meet his family’s daily living expenses.  His wife takes care of their seven children, maintains the home, and sells a variety of vegetables in the busy local Pursat Market.  Leng S. is requesting this loan to buy several cows currently available at cheap prices in order to sell them later.

loans.use: To buy several cows to sell later

loans.name: Shiela

texts.en: Shiela A. is from the city of Ozamis, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Shiela owns and operates a motorcycle transport business, providing motor services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Shiela joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her seventh from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Yoeung

texts.en: Yoeung M., a 39-year-old resident of Kompong Tom Province, earns a living by raising pigs in a stall next to her house. She raises two lots of pigs per year and sells them to the slaughterer every six months, earning an income of approximately $2 a day since 1990.  She is married with four children who attend school and are dependent on her income. Her husband is currently contributing to the family's living expenses by constructing the neighbor's fishing boat. Due to the need for more income to support the family, Yoeung M. is requesting a loan to buy a cow which she will use to transport carving wood from the forest for sale.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Adelfa

texts.en: Adelfa D. is from the town of Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Adelfa owns and operates a sari-sari or general store, selling daily-use products such as soap, shampoo, toothpaste, etc., in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Adelfa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Adelfa is requesting a new loan of 16,817 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her seventh from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhom C., 38, is widow with one young son. She lives in a small village along national road number four about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokhom has been renting a space of her house to garment factory workers sine 1991. Because her house located near garment factory, so it’s good for her to run the business. But, some room is breaks thus she is applying for her first loan of $500 in order to make the repairs.

loans.use: To repair her rooms to rent.

loans.name: Theng

texts.en:
Theng D., a 30-year-old married father, currently owns an old motorcycle which he has used to transport passengers around his community for fees since 2004, typically generating an income of $5 a day. His wife cares for the children and cooks meals for the family. 

Theng D. says that he is very happy to have a profitable business that allows him to meet his entire family's needs, especially his three children's need to get quality educations. However, recently his income has declined due to his motor taxi requiring frequent repair, so he has decided to seek a loan in order to replace it.

loans.use: To replace his existing taxi

loans.name: Matiullah

texts.en:
Matiullah is the son of R.. He lives in district 16th of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 40 and married with four children.

Matiullah would like to repair his house and to buy the essential construction materials for it. So he has requested a loan of 50,000 Afghani.

Matiullah would like to mention that Kiva is an effective process that supports the ones who really need money.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials to repair his house

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mr. Seng S., 45, was married in 1983 and has three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of his children work in a plywood factory and the youngest one is in a local school. The family lives along National Road Number Six about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Seng was not available for the photo and so his wife is shown instead.

Seng and his wife have been growing vegetables for over ten years. They sell their products to a middleman who comes to buy them at their house and who then sells them in Phnom Penh.

Seng is now requesting his second loan of US$250. He will use the loan to continue his farming business.

loans.use: To invest in his business

loans.name: Murad Group

texts.en:
Murad, who is the group leader of Murad Group, is married and lives in Jalalabad, Nangarhar province.

Murad is a very hardworking man.  After a lot of hard work, he made a group of three members, each one of whom is busy in a different task: Murad is busy in his vegetable shop; Abdulwodud is a taxi driver; and M. Anwar is a mechanic. Each group member wants to become stronger in his business so therefore they requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani.

Each member needs 10,000 Afghani to further their work and be a good client for Kiva and AFS. They can repay the loan on time and Murad can control the whole group.

Murad would like to say that this is a good process of loans in Jalalabad, Afghanistan.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Phat

texts.en:
Mr. Phat P., 44, and his wife, Mrs. San Kheak, 43, have been married since 1987. They have five children: two daughters - one of them is married and another one is a garment factory worker; and three sons - two attend school and one stays at home. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Phat has been fishing for over twenty years, while his wife has been growing vegetables for over five years. He is applying for his first loan of $150 in order to purchase fishing nets for his fishing business. He will use part of the loan to help his wife in her business growing vegetables as well.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets for his fishing business and to help his wife's business growing vegetables

loans.name: Rene

texts.en:
Rene D. is the 44-year-old father of three children from Sto. Nino, South Cotabato, Mindanao. His eldest child is 18 years old and, as a father, Rene is worried about the future college education of his children. His business is rice farming. This is his only source of living that has sustained his family for a long time now.

Rene has been a Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) client since 2002 and has kept a good repayment record on all his loans. He is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI which he will use to buy farming materials, to pay for the laborers for his upcoming harvest, and to start another business to augment his income.

Rene said he likes CEVI a lot because it gives him not just loans but insurance and a low interest rate as well.

loans.use: To buy farming materials, to pay laborers and to start another business

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Ma. Fe N. owns and manages a small piggery. Currently she has a sow, which she feeds and bathes every day. She lets her sow produces piglets, and the young pigs produced by the sow are sold for 2,000 PHP each. This has been her business since 1998. She has two children, the eldest being 10 years old, who are her inspiration to perform better in her business. 

She needs a loan of 8,000 PHP. She will use the loan to construct a durable barn and buy additional feed for her pigs. The loan is truly worthwhile because she doesn’t have funds to use to support her business. 

She chose CEVI because they offer a very low interest loan, plus insurance coverage awaits CEVI borrowers.

loans.use: Piglets and feed

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn S. is a 39-year-old mother of three kids. Her eldest is 15 years old. Her dreams for her children are for them to grow into responsible people and be able to pursue college degrees in the future. Her business is rice farming. She grows rice and earns enough to feed and clothe her family well. 

She requested a loan of Php 15,000 to buy farming materials. She will also use some of it to buy piglets and feed for her small piggery.

She said CEVI helps her small business to grow. It provides not just loans but education as well.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet M. age 31 is married to a farmer Virgilio M. age 48. In the long years of their marriage they given a two sons, Jan Vergel, 9 years old and he is now in grade 3 in primary level of education, and the other one is Jezreel who is now 4 years old. 

As of now the sources of their income is through farming business that personally manage by his husband Virgillo. This business starts after they got married, when their families lend them a small part of rice field that are ready for cultivation, and they will rent this. This business runs for 10 years now, but still renting the rice field. Janet really hoping to own a rice field someday, that’s why she does all the possible ways to make the business grow bigger. So she decided to get a loan again from Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) that will be use in buying things that are needed in the farm like fertilizer and pesticides. She also uses the loan in buying pigs and chickens that needed in her poultry business, the other sources of their income. This poultry business starts when she got her first loan in ASHI, and until now it gives them an extra income.

Janet and Virgilio swear that they will do their best to give their children a better education preparing for their future.

loans.use: To finance her poultry and rice farming business

loans.name: Toshpulatova

texts.ru: Тошпулатова Обида проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст 52 года. Вдова, имеет 3 детей. Сын также работает и помогает матери. Сама Обида более 8 лет  занимается торговлей, т.е. бизнесом. Она в основном торгует продуктами питания, которые закупает в городе а потом у себя продает подороже. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
O. Toshpulatova lives in the Tursun-zodf region. She is 52, a widow, and has 3 children. Her son also works and helps her. O. has been in sales for the past 8 years. Mainly, she sells food, which she purchases in the city and then resells at higher prices. She is asking for additional funding to increase her inventory.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase inventory

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn L. has been a CEVI client for seven years now. She has a rice farm that secures all her family's needs, including food and other costs in their home. Her 2-hectare farm produces an average of 180 sacks per harvest. She has seven children who are not living with her anymore. Her eldest is 35. She has grandchildren, who she also supports. 

She needs additional capital to finance her farm. She would like to request a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy farming supplies. She will also use some of the loans to start another business, to supplement the family income.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina C. has two children. The eldest is 43 years old and already married.

Cristina’s business is rice farming, and this keeps her busy every day. Currently, she has less than a hectare (2.5 acres) of rice field. The average size of her harvest is ninety sacks, which is helpful enough in buying her needs.

Cristina is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI ). She will use the loan to finance all her farming needs. She will also use some of her loan to raise chickens or start another business that she likes.

Cristina said, she likes the credit policies of CEVI. Aside from the low interest rate of 2% a month, CEVI has good field staff who implement the program.

loans.use: To finance all her farming needs and to raise chickens or start another business

loans.name: Haide

texts.en:
Haide C. is a 57 year old mother of five. Her eldest is 29 and not living with them anymore. She joined CEVI in 2002 because her friend convinced her to join. Because she likes the policy and the interest rate ( 2% a month) of her loan, she has stuck with the program for seven years now. Her business is rice farming; she has been helping her husband till a 1.5 hectare farm to have an income to feed and clothe her family.

She is asking for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farming necessities and start a new business as well. Aside from farm she also raises pigs. She will also buy piglets and feed.

loans.use: Farming and piggery supplies

loans.name: Inobat

texts.ru: Инобат Усмонова проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст 48 лет. Замужем, имеет 1 ребенка. Инобат более 20 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она занимается продажей национальный "тюбитеек". У нее имеется постоянный поставщик, который поставляет ей подешевле, а она на рынке продает их подороже. Муж работает на частной стройке. Кредит просит для пополнения оборотных средств.
texts.en:
Inobat U. lives in Tursun-zoda region. She is 48, married, and has one child. Inobat has been in sales for more than 20 years. She sells national hats called "tubeteyka." She has a supplier that provides her with low-priced hats, which she later resells at higher prices on a market. Her husband works at private construction. She is asking for a loan to increase her inventory.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Joebert

texts.en:
Joebert L. is a goat herder. He has farm animals that he feeds every day. Aside from goat, he is also raising pigs and chickens to be able to provide his family an adequate food to live. Currently, he has 5 goats, 1 sow and 4 pigs. He aimed to breed more animals to earn an income and save enough for the future. 

Now, he needs additional capital to run the business that he had. He requested a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to reconstruct a bigger barn for his goat, a coop for the chickens,  feed as well as piglets for his piggery.

He has three children, 10 years old the eldest who keeps him inspired everyday to perform better in his business ventures

loans.use: To construct a bigger barn and buy feed for pigs

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia C. is 40 years old is a rice grower. She has no child but a husband who is very supportive of her in all her endeavors. She started helping her spouse tilling a 1-hectare farm last 2000. From then on, she learns to love the soil as well as the rice plant because this is their only source of living to buy her whole family needs.

She requested a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farming necessities. She would like also to use her loan to some other business that she likes to be able to augment their family income. 

Getting comfortable with CEVI services, she said, that she will continue to avail a loan in CEVI because it has the lowest interest rate compared to other micro finance that 
lent to her before.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a member of the Makange borrower group in KIboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 23 year old woman, She is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 1 year old. 

Amina has owned a food business selling tomatoes, potatoes, onions 3 years ago, She works 12 hours a day and earns mothly profit approximetly 30,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Amina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh order to buy more tomatoes,potatoes, onions, for sale.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this ,Amina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes,onions,potatoes

loans.name: Niel

texts.en:
Niel F. is 44-year-old mother of 3 children. She is a pig grower and currently having 1 sow that produces piglets, which she sells for Php 1, 800 each.
