She wanted to grow her business to be able to support the college education of her children. Aside from pigs, her family also raises native chickens to provide an adequate food to live. 

She needs a loan to support her business growth. Receiving a loan of Php 8,000 is truly worthwhile since she doesn’t have money to buy new piglets and feed. 

While everyone is dreaming about business success, her dreams are, her children will grow as responsible persons and do whatever is right to help other people.

loans.use: piglets and feed

loans.name: Pannha

texts.en:
Mr. Pannha A. is a plaster decorator. He was married in 2007 and lives with his wife, who is a garment factory worker, and his mother on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Pannha doesn’t have his own transportation, so he is applying for a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie C. feeds and bathes her pigs every day. She has a sow that produces an average of twelve piglets and she sells the young pigs for Php 1,900 each. She said that working in the barn is very hard work, but it’s a feasible business because people buy meat all the time.

Tessie needs a loan of Php 8,000 to support her piggery. She will use the loan to buy feed and also piglets for fattening.

Tessie has three children, and she dreams of having a very successful business to support their needs.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a member of the KDC borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 27 year old woman, she is single.

Flora has owned a cafe business selling food 1 year. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Flora second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more  cooking oil, wheat flour for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Flora hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more wheat  flour, cooking oil

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
This old, small wooden house located in the rural area of Pursat Province belongs to Mrs. Kong S., 48, a local farmer. She is married to Mob Toy, 52, and they have six children. Two of their children are married and live independently, while the other four are single, do not have long in school and work on the farm. Her husband is a poultry raiser.

In the past, Kong S. always hired a neighbor’s buffalo at high fees in order to allow her to do the hard physical labor of plowing a field. She now hopes to own a water buffalo by using a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL. The loan will provide her with an extra asset.

loans.use: To buy a water buffalo

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora S. is from the village of Mamanga Gamay. She is 44 years old. Flora is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Flora raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Flora is just starting this business.

In 2008, Flora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers like manure. Flora is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Flora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa T., 47, is the mother of two children and a rice farmer. She started helping her husband till the wet field in 1985. All her work helped a lot with buying the daily needs of their home, including school payments and other projects. 

”Glory to God, my business is doing good,” she said. And now, she wants to increase the size of her farm. She wants to venture into something else like food to supplement their income. She needs a loan of Php 6,000 to buy farm necessities and start a new business. 

She withdrew from CEVI before but decided to rejoin. She realized that CEVI has the lowest interest rate and it offers not just credit but also insurance coverage.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Cate's Group

texts.en: S. Cate is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a friendly, determined and hard working married lady with a salon business in Nakisunga town and it has been running for 18 years. She is a happy woman with good ways of handling her customers in addition to the experience she has and she is grateful because she is able to make some profits that in turn help to boost her business. Cate has dreams of expanding her business by starting another branch and this will enable her to give a much stronger helping hand in addition to her husband’s contribution. However, her main business challenge is having customers that do not want to pay on time for the services rendered and this affects her cash flow. She has 7 children and takes care of 1 orphan and the eldest of her children is at the University with a lot of school fees to pay. Cate needs a loan to be able to buy more hair oils, cosmetics and hair pieces for more stock.

loans.use: Buying more hair oiuls, cosmetics and hair pieces for the salon.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a member of the Majengo borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 32 year old woman, She is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 12 and 4 years old.

Monica has owned a charcoal business for 8 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Monica`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Monica hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Pabling

texts.en:
Pabling T. is a rice grower from Trento, Agusan Del Sur. He is 56 years old and has only one child that is 13 years now. He is tilling a 2 hectare farm that he already owned for quite along time already to be able to provide his family an adequate food to live. 

 Now, he would like to request a loan of Php 14,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to finance his farm like buying the seeds and payment for the laborer who prepares the land before it was planted with rice seedlings.

He is now on his 5th loan in CEVI. The reason why she keeps joining the program is because of insurance coverage and small interest rate.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Sam-At

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam-at D., age 37, and her husband, Mr. Roeung Nem, live in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City, were married in 1999. They have one son who attends school. 

Sam-at has a full-time employment in a hotel. Her husband is a driver; he drives for the ministry of information. By the way, the house where the family lives breaks down in some parts that’s why Sam-at is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to in order to make the repairs.

loans.use: To repair her house where she lives.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a member of the Mnazi mmoja borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 32 Year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 15 and 18 years old. She also cares for other 2 dependent.

Elizabeth has owned a food business selling banana,potatoes, oranges etc for  8 years, she works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately  200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Elizabeth`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities  for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Elizabeth hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more food product

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura M. owns and manages a 2.5-hectare rice field. She has two children, with the eldest 18 years old. Her children keep her inspired to perform better in her business to provide a good future for the family. Aside from rice, the family also tills a 1.5-hectare cornfield that supplements their overall income. 

She is asking for a loan of Php 14,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to finance farm necessities and start another business. 

She said this is her fifth loan from CEVI and she wishes to use its services more in the future.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Christine's Group

texts.en:
Christine N. is a 40-year-old married lady with four children, with the eldest being 18 years old and in secondary school. She also helps to take care of two orphans who are also in school. 

Christine has had a butcher shop in Kisowera trading centre for five years and she is able to make 100,000UGX in profit a week. She employs a man to help her with the cutting of the meat in pieces for sale, although at times, she does the work herself. 

She has a plan to buy a plot and build her own house so that she can stop renting and save that for future developments. Christine needs a loan to help buy more meat for her butcher shop so that she could make more profit. She is such a friendly and easy-to-approach lady, and this keeps her going.

loans.use: Buying more meat for resale in the butcher shop.

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca is a member of the Kidumu borrower group in Kiboriloni , Kilimanjaro, She is 38 year old woman, She is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 15,11,8,5 years old. She also cares for other 1 dependent.

Prisca has owned a clothing business selling clothes for  5 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 30,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Prisca`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more used clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Prisca hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda N. is from the village of Mamanga Daku. She is 46 years old. Nilda is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Nilda owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. Nilda has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Nilda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nilda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Nilda is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the seventh loan Nilda has received from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom is a silk weaver; she operates a silk-weaving business at her house located in Kosh Dach. Kosh Dach is an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. It’s a skill she learned from her parent. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then in turn sells it in Phnom Penh market. Her husband, Mr. Tev Ros, is a security guard. In the past, he used to be a motor taxi driver. 

Mom has asked for a loan one time already. She is now requesting another loan of $1,200 to purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business, and she will use a part of her loan to buy cow and ox to raise as well.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business and buy cow and ox to raise.

loans.name: Geneva

texts.en:
Geneva is a member of the Sokoni borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro.she is 35 year old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are aged 11 and 5 years old. She also cares for other 2 dependent.

Geneva has owned her own business selling tomatoes,potatoes,onions etc for 8 years ago. She works 8 hours a day and earns monthly profit approximately 50,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Geneva`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities to her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Geneva hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes,potatoes, onion

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a member of the Msangara borrower group in kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 48 year old woman. She is widowed and a mother of 9 children. Her children are 32,30,28,26,24,22,20,18, 16 years old.

Fatuma has owned a fruits business(oranges) for 7 years, She works 8 hours a day and earns monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.


This is Fatuma`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more fruits for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Fatuma hopes to save more money and expand her fruits business.

loans.use: To buy more Fruits(oranges)

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet M. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 31 years old. Janet is single and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Janet owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Janet is just starting this business.

In 2008, Janet joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Janet is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Janet from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Sreypov

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreypov C. lives with her husband, Mr. Pich Pin and her children on an Island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Her husband is a hairdresser.

Sreypov is a silk weaver and she sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. She doesn’t have enough capital to purchase raw materials (silk, cotton thread), so she is requesting a loan of US$300 to make the purchases.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business and buy cow and ox to raise.

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda C. helps her husband till a 3 hectare farm that was given to them by her parents. She's helped her husband with the farm since the start of their marriage. She has five children (the oldest is 19) that gives her the strength to fight and succeed in business.

She would like a loan of 14,000 PHP to buy seeds and pay for labour for her farm. She says she likes the services of CEVI because, aside from the fact that it is very manageable to repay, you learn a lot of things from the cluster meetings and there is biblical reflection in CEVI.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Jamirah's Group

texts.en:
N. Jamirah is 28 years old and a single mother of four children between the ages of 3 and 12. She also takes care of her young sister, Najjuko Faridah. Jamirah sells roasted plantains (gonja) at the Namawojjolo market. She has been in business for 15 years, selling to customers in vehicles on the Jinja road highway. One challenge she has here, is that customers at times go with the gonja without paying for them, reducing her profit. She is able to make a profit of 100,000/= a week, and she still hopes for better.

Jamirah is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She has a dream of owning a retail shop in Namawojjolo, where she hopes to make more profits due to her good customer service. After that, she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house for her children. She needs a loan to help expand her business by buying gonjas in bulk which reduces the cost of purchase.

loans.use: To buying 'gonjas' for roasting

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a member of the Msangara borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 40 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 28,25,22 years old. She also cares for other 2 dependents.

Rose has owned clothing business selling clothes for 3 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns  a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Rose`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Rose hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Rosane

texts.en:
Rosanne P. owns a 3-hectare rice field. Her parents give the 2 hectares to them while they started to gain much from their harvest; they were also able to buy the other 1-hectare that augment their family income. She has three children, 13 years the eldest who give her the strength of pursuing more in business. She is a CEVI client for a quite long time now. Currently, it is her 5th loan . She likes the services because the interest rate is just 2 % a month.

She requested another loan of Php 14,000  to finance the needs in her farm. She will use the loan to buy rice seeds and to pay the laborer as well that toils hard in preparing the land.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Yutema

texts.en: Mr. Yutema has been a construction contractor for three years. He is 44 years old and his wife, Mrs. Saroth Horn, is 25 years old. They were married in 2000 and have no children yet. His wife stays at home. They live along National Road No. 1, about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Yutema is applying for his first loan of $350 to pay for worker fees.

loans.use: To pay for workers fees in his construction contractor business

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa T. is from the village of Usocan. She is 44 years old. Leonisa is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Leonisa owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Leonisa has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Leonisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Leonisa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Leonisa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Joylyn

texts.en:
Joylyn D. has a small rice field in Trento Agusan del Sur. She was able to inherit a 1.5-hectare farm from her parents, which she keeps productive to make them proud. She has two children. Her eldest is 8 years old and currently studying in elementary school near their home. This is her fifth loan from CEVI. The reason why she has stayed so long in the program is that CEVI has affected her life. Before, she might have sold her farm but because CEVI offers her a loan that has the lowest interest rate of 2% a month, she was able to recover from a great loss and able to keep her farm.

Now, she needs again a loan of Php 14,000 to finance farming necessities. She will be buying seeds and paying the laborers that toil hard to prepare the land. The loan will truly help her sustain her livelihood.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Mhlali Group

texts.en:
Mhlali is the group leader of Mhlali group. There are four members in this group. Each of them wants a loan to expand their business. They are requesting a group of loan 40000 Afghani. 

Mhlali and Zhaki want the loan for theirs husbands who are taxi drivers. Najeba wants a loan for her husband who has a butcher shop. Jameil wants a loan for her husband who has a metal workshop. 

They are very happy about the loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Jenifer's Group

texts.en:
N. Jenifer is a strong and determined lady who is willing to succeed through hard work. She is 42 years old and a widow with two children ages 20 and 24. She also cares for other siblings. 

She has a retail shop. She has been a shopkeeper for five years and is able to make 100,000UGX a week, which in turn helps her to take care of her family including paying their school fees. Before this, Jenifer was a poultry farmer but is now happy that her friendliness and accountability have kept her in business. 

In the future, she wants to become a wholesale supplier of goods so that she can sell more. She also envisions seeing all her children and those she takes care of attain the best of education so that they can get better jobs for self-sustainability. Jenifer needs a loan to help add more capital to her shop since this brings about stability in the supply of products and the smooth running of the business.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more products.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa R. is 41 years old rice grower from Trento, Agusan del Sur Mindanao. She owns a 2-hectare farm.  She bought the farm out from her small savings when she was single. The farm is truly a gift since; this provides the needs in their family especially food, clothing as well as the education of her 4 children.  She has been a client of Community Economic Ventures Inc. for a long time now. Apparently, it’s her 5th loan in CEVI and she wished to stay long because she likes the services and the bonding of the members in their CEVI cluster organization. Another thing that she likes is the insurance coverage services that CEVI offers to all its members. She also likes the way CEVI brings the education to people. Truly it’s more than financial that CEVI implements in its covered communities.

Now, Elsa would like to avail a loan a gain of Php 14,000. She will use the loan to finance the farm necessities. She will buy seeds and pay the laborers and that toils hard in preparing the farm ready for planting..

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Edmundo

texts.en:
Edmundo M. is the father of five children. He is 62 years old and still plowing with the carabao, a farm animal typically used by Filipinos to plow fields. Currently, he owns a 1-hectare farm that he bought from his little savings when he was younger. 

He needs a loan to support the needs in his rice field. A loan of Php 14,000 will help him buy sacks of rice seeds and pay the laborers who helped prepare the land for planting. 

He said this is his fifth loan from CEVI. He has stayed this long in the program because he likes the services and the staff is very friendly as well.

loans.use: To buy sack of rice seeds and other farming needs

loans.name: Borann

texts.en:
Mrs. Borann P., 48, is widow, lives in a small village a long National Road Number five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She has been operating grocery store since 1986. 
Borann used to apply for a loan from Kiva through MAXIMA. She is now asking for another loan in the amount of $300 purchase grocery items for continuing her business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for continuing her selling grocery business.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama Z. is from the village of Lower Bayao, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 61 years old. Salama is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Salama owns and operates a transportation services business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating jeepney transport services (a popular means of public transportation in the Philippines). Salama has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 8,400 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Salama joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Salama is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair existing vehicles for better service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Salama from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicles for better service

location.town: Lower Bayao, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a member of the Miembeni borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 42 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 18,14,9, and 7 years old.

Fatuma has owned a clothing business selling clothes  for 12 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a mothnly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Fatuma`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan. Fatuma hopes to pay school fees. get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for sale

loans.name: Nimol

texts.en:
Mrs. Nimol O., 26, and her husband, Mr. Chenda So, 24, were married in 2007 and have two children: one son and one daughter. The family lives on an island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Nimol is a tailor. Besides her tailoring business, she is a silk weaver as well. Her husband has been a mason for four years. He works in Phnom Penh. Nimol hopes to create another new business selling rice wine; it will better for her to earn extra income to support her family. Thus, she is requesting her first loan of US$200 to purchase rice wine for resale.

loans.use: To purchase rice wine for resale.

loans.name: Damali's Group

texts.en:
N. Damali is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 30 years old and married with four children ages 13, 9, 3 and 2 years. She also takes care of other siblings, all in primary school. 

Damali has had a business selling agricultural produce like tomatoes, onions, green bananas, sweet potatoes and so on at the Lugazi Central market for three years. She started slowly with very limited capital but now her business has grown and her major challenge is that at times the produce is so scarce hence affecting business. Due to her quality goods, she now has many customers.

She would like to become a supplier to others in the agricultural produce business, and she would also liketo build a residential house for her family. Her profit is 60,000UGX a week and she would need a loan to be able to add more capital to her business since the profits help her to pay school fees for her children. Damali is such a hard-working lady and with more capital, the sky is the limit for her success.

loans.use: Buying more agricultural products like tomatoes, onions, green bananas and more for her business.

loans.name: Bibi Khdiga Group

texts.en:
Bibi Khdiga is the group leader of the Bibi Khdiga Group. There are four members in this group. They want a loan to expand their businesses, so they have requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani. 

Bibi Khdiga wants a loan for her husband who has a cigarette cart. Shime wants loan for his tailoring business. D. M. wants a loan for his general store. Basmallah wants a loan for her cosmetics shop. 

They are very happy about the loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a member of the Miembeni borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 21 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 1 year old.

Saumu has owned a clothing business selling clothes for 2 years, she works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 60,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Saumu`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania. She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Saumu hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Min

texts.en: The two people shown in the picture above are Mrs. Min M. and her husband. This couple has given birth to three children who go to school or work. Min M. retails fresh fish in the local market. She sells fish that she gets either from her husband’s fishing or buys from her wholesale suppliers and other fishermen. Min M. requests a loan as capital to allow her husband to purchase more nets, traps and boat machine in order to better supply his fishing activities.

loans.use: To purchase more nets, traps and boat machine in order to better support fishing activities

loans.name: Chamnab

texts.en:
Mrs. Chamnab, age 30, was married in 2001 and has two children. She lives with her mother and her brother and sister in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Her daughter is a teacher.

Chamnab is a silk weaver; additionally she also sells silk fabric. She buys it from other weavers in her village for resale in Phnom Penh market. 

Chamnab has asked for a loan one time already. Her sister doesn’t have her own transportation, so Chamnab is requesting her second loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for her sister for commuting to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her sister for commuting to work.

loans.name: Parey Gul Group

texts.en:
Parey G. is the group leader of the Parey G. Group. There are four members in this group. They want a loan to improve and expand their businesses, so they are requesting a group loan of 40000 Afghani. 

Parey G. wants a loan for her husband who has a wood shop. Shellah wants a loan for her bag weaving business. Jamela wants a loan for her tailoring business. Fatama wants a loan for her husband, who is a taxi driver. 

They are very thankful to all Kiva lenders who support entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To improve their businesses

loans.name: Mr. Tha Sok Group Loan

texts.en: Mr. Tha S. is a group leader of four members who all live in Pratheat village in Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. He owns an electric cow (a machine used to plow the field), but now it has a problem. Thus, he decided to request for a loan to fix his electric cow. His wife, Mrs. Touk Pao, sells boiled corn. Mr. Tha S. is 48 years old and the father of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To request a loan to fix his electric cow.

loans.name: Sentongo's Group

texts.en: N. Sentongo is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 42 years and married with 5 children aged between 22 – 12 years as she cares for other siblings. She is a business lady involved in the sale of agricultural produce in Lugazi Central market for 15 years. Mostly she sells tomatoes and cabbages which she started so small with a few bags of the produce but now has more with a possibility of making 100,000/= a week due to her quality produce and the ability of her sellers to pay in time. She also wants to join another business by owning a retail shop in future and later move into a wholesale department. She needs a loan to be able to add more capital into her agricultural produce selling business since this widens the supply of her produce.

loans.use: Buying tomatoes and cabbages and at times matooke for resale.

loans.name: Mrs. Tanglet Thai Group Loan

texts.en:
Mrs. Tanglet T. is a group leader of four who all live in Preak Thmei village in Kandal province. She is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more grocery products for selling to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Vong Choeurn, is a hairdresser. Mrs. Tanglet T. is 54 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are workers while another is a hairdresser; one is enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. 

One member in this group has end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to earn more income.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Twenty-eight year-old Chanthy N. was married in 2001 and has three children: two sons and one daughter. She lives on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chanthy has been a silk weaver since she was 17 years old. Her husband has been a full time driver since 2008. She is requesting her first loan of US$100 to purchase silk materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a member of the mnazi 8 borrower group in kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 28 year old woman, she is single.


Salome has owned a shoes business for 2 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.


This is Salome`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania. She requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more shoes for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Salome hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for sale

loans.name: Suzan's Group

texts.en:
Suzan N. is the leader of this lending group, based in Lugazi. She is thirty years old and married with four children. In total she cares for ten dependents. Suzan has been selling new clothes in Kiyindi market for ten years and, although her business is seasonal with stiff competition, she is able to continue due to her unique products and good customer care.

Suzan has a dream of owning a shop rather than working in the market, so as to be best placed to look after her family. She also hopes to educate her family and build her own house to rent out. Suzan needs a loan to be able to pay her children’s school fees and buy more stock for her business.

loans.use: Buy clothes stocks and pay children's school fees

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato B. is a married twenty-three year-old from the village of Sta. Cruz. To make a living, Renato owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Renato has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately PHP10,000 a month for these activities.

This year Renato joined PMPC to gain access to financial services in order to improve his living situation and business. Renato is requesting a new loan of PHP 25,000 that will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Renato from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Hour

texts.en:
Mrs. Hour H., age 45, pictured with her husband and her children, lives across the Mekong River and about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been selling fish for three years. She buys them from the market to resell in the village. Her husband is a fisherman. He sells cows as well. They were married in 1985 and have four sons and two daughters. Two of their sons sell coconuts, three children attend school and the youngest one stays at home.

Mrs. Hour H. is requesting a loan of $700 to buy a boat and fishing materials for her husband’s fishing business and to purchase cows for resale.

loans.use: To purchase a boat and fishing materials and to buy cows

loans.name: Mr. Ly Chheun Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
Mr. Ly C. fishes in the lake in his village. He is 52 years old and the father of eight children: two of them are employed in a garment factory, two others are electricians, two are enrolled in the local school, and the others are too young to work or study. His wife, Mrs. Bou Sear, is a farmer who owns a 1 hectare field of land to cultivate rice.

Mr. Ly C. needs a fishery boat and has decided to request a loan to deal this problem. He is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. This village bank consists of 17 people who live in Lvea Sar Kandal village in Kandal province.

loans.use: To buy a fishery boat

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en:
V., a 54-year-old woman, lives in the "Kingdom of Wonder" capital, Phnom Penh. She has been a silk weaver for 29 years – a skill she learned from her grandmother. She sells her finished product to a middleman, who then takes it to re-sell at the local market and supermarket. V. has also been hired by the villagers to spin silk, from which she earns extra income.

V. has been married for years and has eight children: five of them are single, and the others are married and have already started new homes. Most of her children assist her with weaving silk. Her husband has been farming for years. V. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase more silk materials to continue her business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials

loans.name: Lonimar

texts.en:
Lonimar L. is from the village of Lao Proper. He is 45 years old. Lonimar is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Lonimar owns and operates a business selling baked goods in the local community. Lonimar has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately $315 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Lonimar joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Lonimar is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be Lonimar's first loan from Lonimar from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Goreth's Group

texts.en: B. Goreth is 42 years old and the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She has five children and also cares for orphaned children. Goreth has had a beauty salon in Nyenga for fifteen years. She worked as a tailor before that. In her current business, she is mostly affected by the high prices of products that she uses, which leave her with a profit of only about $51 a week. She hopes to expand her business more and to educate all her children to the University level so that they can find good jobs. Goreth needs a loan for working capital. This will help her be sure of having a steady supply of products even when the prices are high.

loans.use: To buy more salon products to generate increased profits.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Prudencio S. 49 years old, find a good and a helpful partner in life after marrying Teresita S. 43 years old. Teresita helps her husband in making income for their family. Her husband is a farmer so the main source of their income comes from farming, but because they do not own the rice field they’ll not getting all the revenue from the farming of rice, they’ll only getting percentage on it. So Teresita think of another business aside from that. As of now, she has a variety store that sell different goods that needed by the people living nearby houses and also a store that sell batchoy, a noodle soup that mostly Filipino eat, both this business contributes in their income. This business comes from the loan that she loan in ASHI.

Now, Teresita wants again to help her husband in growing the business that he manages, which is the farming rice business. She will have a loan again to Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) for buying fertilizers and other things that are needed in making the business of her husband to grow so that someday they will have their own rice field to cultivate.

Also Teresita is a loving mother to their only son Jerry who is now 26 years old. She is hoping that he will give him a better life and a happy family.

loans.use: Will be used to finance her rice farming business

loans.name: Mrs. Koen Hang Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
Eleven people who are living in Pouthi Reamea village in Kandal province are members of the Village Bank Loan Group. Mrs. Koen H. is a the group president who has been selected by the members. They will each use the loan for different purposes. She is a pig breeder. Since her breeding pigs business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Em Leang, is a hard-working man. This couple has six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another helps the parents work, and the others are attending the local school. 

Six members of this group loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthL. payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Mrs. Eng Phann Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
A village bank loan group which consists of fifteen people is located in Pouthi Reamea village in Kandal province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Eng P. is the village bank president. She is the wife of a fisherman, Mr. Chi Chorb. He does not have enough fishnets and this affects his income. Mrs. Eng P. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishnets for her husband’s fishing. She is a 39-year-old mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study. 

Twelve members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK H. a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK H. a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets for her husband’s fishing.

loans.name: Shah Tours Group

texts.en:
Modesta is a membe of the Shah tours borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro, She is 40 year old woman, She is married and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 21, 20, 15, 10 years old. She also cares for other 4 dependents.

Modesta has owned a clothing business selling clothes for 15 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 40,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is  Modesta`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Modesta hopes to save more money and  expand her business.

Salome is another member of the same borrower group, she also requested the loan amount 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more  clothes

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia T. is thirty-six years old and a widow. She has three children, one boy and two girls who are both in school at the primary level. She is taking care of three other dependents who are also in school. Lydia runs a bar selling beer, wine, sodas, and so on. Her business is located in Kiyirikiti village that is in Nyendo, in the Masaka district. She is using the loan to purchase more crates of beer, soda, wines, and boxes of water to sell to her customers. Her business dream is to increase her inventory by purchasing different types of alcohol, which would enable her to really increase her average daily sales.  Even more, she dreams of educating her children to the university level.

loans.use: To buy more beer, soda, wines, water, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Yan

texts.en: Yan N. is 54 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than ten years. She sells fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing or buys them from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She is married to Sean Yart, age 58, who works at fishing in and around the lakes of his community. Currently, the fishing is temporarily interrupted because the fishing equipment is broken. Because of this reason, that is why Yan N. requested a loan for capital to allow her husband to buy additional fishing equipment. Note: Yan N. was not available for photographing at that time, so her husband appears in the picture instead.

loans.use: To buy additional fishing equipment

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr: Cette jeune dame est mariée et est mère d’un enfant. Elle habite le quartier Adidogomé à Lomé. C’est une vendeuse ambulante de bijoux de qualité. Elle s’approvisionne au Bénin et au Ghana les deux pays voisins. Elle vend le plus souvent à des femmes d’affaires du secteur privé, à des femmes fonctionnaires et à des jeunes filles étudiantes de l’Université de Lomé comme clientes. Elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour faire de nouvelles commandes de bijoux au Ghana et au Bénin. Elle exerce cette activité depuis 2003.
texts.en:
This young lady is married and the mother of one child.  She lives in the Adidogomé district of Lomé.  She is an itinerant seller of quality jewelry.  She stocks up in Benin and in Ghana, which are two neighboring countries.  Usually she sell to business women in the private sector, to women civil servants, and to girl students at the University of Lomé, all as her customers.  She's requesting a WAGES loan for new orders of jewelry from Ghana and Benin.  She has been in this business since 2003.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy jewelry to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth América

texts.es: Elizabeth América H. D. F. vive en el departamento D. La Libertad junto su esposo don Jose D.  71 años D. edad, que a pesar D. su cansancio por la edad aun sigue trabajando como seguridad D. un rancho D. la zona. Elizabeth también cuenta con el apoyo D. su hija Anita D. 18 años D. edad, quien ayuda en el negocio, donD. todas los días se elaboran tortillas y a su vez se encuentra la tienda con productos D. consumo diario; el anhelo D. Elizabeth es hacer crecer su tienda; ya que su poca variedad D. productos hacen que sus ventas no incrementen, con la ayuda D. este crédito Elizabeth podrá surtir su negocio y obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Elizabeth América H. D. F. lives in the province of La Libertad with her husband Jose, who at 71 is an active worker in spite of his age, holding down a job in security at a local ranch. Elizabeth is helped by her daughter, Anita who is18 and helps her with the business of making tortillas and attending to daily meals; Elizabeth's greatest wish is to grow her small store's business, as currently the limited variety of products constrains business growth. With the help of this loan, Elizabeth expects to better stock the store and obtain better sales.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Cassetta, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase Stock and Product Variety in Store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and to hire labor to work in the field.

loans.name: Sroeun

texts.en: Mrs. Sroeun G. lives in Khsom village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Ei Rean, are farmers who earn a living by cultivating rice on a plot of land that they own. They do not have enough money to buy the farm supplies they need, so Mrs. Sroeun G. decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer and a pump. She would use the rest of money to buy vegetables to resell in order to earn more income. She is 45 years old and the mother of eight children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another is a farmer.  Of the others, three are enrolled in the local school. The youngest one is just four years old. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and a pump, and also vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Jyldyz's Group

texts.en:
Jyldyz is the leader of this group. At the age of thirty-six, she is divorced and raises two daughters on her own. To earn her small family’s living she works in a nursing home as a matron. Both of her daughters go to school, and as they grow, Jyldyz’s monthly salary of $50 has begun to be insufficient to provide everything for her daughters. So Jyldyz has found herself an extra occupation, selling fruits. Her sister has been selling fruits for many years and once advised her to start doing the same. She helped Jyldyz with the first purchase and now this new activity allows Jyldyz to cover her family’s living expenses. Jyldyz has decided to obtain a loan and purchase fruits in a neighboring region in larger quantities and bring them to her town to sell. This way she would be able to earn more money and make a needed repair at her house. Jyldyz is ready to do everything within her capability to provide her daughters with a good college education. In the near future she is going to open a small shop. 

Jyldyz’s partners are: Zamira, Erkingul and Taasil. Zamira, age 43, has raised four children. She is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband is an excavator operator. Her 19-year-old daughter helps Zamira keep house. Zamira needs a loan to purchase fodder and hay for the cattle.

Erkingul, age 26, has two children. Her husband sells flour. Before, he used to receive flour instead of a salary, which he would exchange for cattle. He would then feed and resell them. Now Erkingul is engaged in raising the cattle. Erkingul needs a loan to purchase calves and fodder for them.

Taasil, age 47, has mothered six children. Most of them have left for Russia to work. Her husband works at a construction site and she bakes bread and manufactures traditional articles. Taasil needs a loan to purchase coal, as winter is approaching. 
======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy fruit in a neighboring region in large quantities for resale locally.

loans.name: Prisila

texts.en:
Prisila is a member of the  mnazi borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 25 year old woman, she is  single.

Prisila has owed a clothing business for 8 years. She works 6 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 40,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Prisila`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, She requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothing for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Prisila hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy mor clothes

loans.name: Santos Marina

texts.es: Santos Marina Z. D. R.  resiD. en San Martin municipio del departamento D. San Salvador. Santos se encuentra casada, vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos, William el esposo D. Santos se dedica a las ventas D. manera ambulante y Santos posee un puesto donD. venD. variedad D. zapatos, esta joven pareja es muy unida, ya que el objetivo D. estos padres es sacar adelante a sus hijos, y poder brindarles una educación. Ahora Santos solicita este crédito para invertir en productos para su negocio el cual tiene ubicado en una buena zona por la afluencia D. personas, con este crédito Santos comprar mayor cantidad y variedad D. productos para ayudar a incrementar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Santos Marina Z. D. R. lives in San Martin, a municipality in the province of San Salvador. Santos is married, and lives with her husband and two children. William, her husband, dedicates his time to traveling sales and Santos has a vendor stand where she sells a variety of shoes; this close young couple has the goal of offering a better future for their children and assuring their education. Santos requests this loan in order to invest in products for her business, which is located in a good area and attracts prosperous clients. She believes this loan will help her offer better inventory and product variety, to produce increased sales.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Cassetta, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Sokchoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokchoun P., age 18, and her husband, Mr. Sienghour Try, age 20, were just married in 2008. They live with their parents in a small village off of National Road number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sokchoun is a garment factory worker, but she stopped working for a while because she is pregnant. Mr. Sienghour is a truck driver. He is hired by people to transport sand, excavated dirt, sandstone and so on, using his own truck. Recently, his truck broke down, which upset his business. That’s why Sokchoun is applying for her first loan of $300 to add to her own money for repairing the truck for her husband. Then he will be able to continue his business.

loans.use: To add to her own money for repairing her husband's truck.

loans.name: Meyeh

texts.fr: Marié et mère d’un enfant cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de boissons alcoolisées. Elle dresse son étalage de marchandises non loin du marché local d’akodessewa. La situation géographique de son activité lui permet de faire de bonne recette. Voulant augmenter son stock de marchandises en prévision des fêtes de fin d’année qui approche pour bien vendre. Elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 cartons de boissons alcoolisées de différentes marques.
texts.en:
A married mother of one child, this lady operates a revenue-generating business selling alcoholic drinks.  She sets up her display of merchandise not far from the local marketplace of Akodessewa.  Her location enables her to make a good income.  Ahead of the year-end holidays approaching, and wanting to augment her stock of merchandise to do well in her sales, she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy 10 boxes of alcoholic beverages of different brands.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy drinks

loans.name: Reginah's Group

texts.en:
N. Reginah is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 57 years old and married with four children, of whom two are still in school. She also takes care of orphans and siblings.

Reginah has been a fish monger at the Lugoba/Kkoba landing site for twenty-nine years, and out of her experience she is able to make weekly profits of $85, which help her in looking after her family and paying the children’s school fees. She is a friendly person and appreciates the contribution that the loans have made in making the success of her business possible.

She hopes to become a supplier of fish to other fish mongers so that she can make more profit. She also hopes to construct a residential house for a rental property. Reginah needs a loan to buy more fish for resale to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more fish for resale to her customers.

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Sin L. is a low-income people living in her own family house at the rural area of Kampong Chhnang Province, where she earns her daily profit by selling cupcakes in the local market. She sells her cakes that she makes herself out of her home. She buys cake ingredient on credit from her market suppliers and she returns her income after she finishes selling. She is married with five single children who assist her in making cupcake, while her husband is an employed worker. He is always hired by neighbor to slaughter their animals. Sin L. would like to borrow a loan to purchase more tools for producing cakes and the rest of loan will buy fish at cheapest price to make fish past to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more tools for producing cakes

loans.name: Mrs. Saroeun Tep Group Loan

texts.en: Mrs. Saroeun T. is a group leader of five members who all live in Tnaot village in Takeo province. She is a silk weaver. Since this business is going well, she has many requests, but she does not have enough silk to meet customers' demands. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Vuth Horn, is a rock breaker. Mrs. Saroeun T. is 43 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are weavers, three of whom are enrolled in the local school, and the youngest of whom is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy silk to make more cloth to meet customer demand

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mr. Thy O., age 53, and his wife, Mrs. Rem Chorn, 50, live in a small village off of National Road Number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1991 and have one son and one daughter. All of them are married and live in separated home. 
Thy has been a fisherman for twenty-one years; he fishes from the lake far away from his house. While his wife sells fish that her husband catches. Besides of selling fish, she raises cows as well. Thy’s wife has asked for a loan one time already. He is now applying for another loan again in amount of $800 to purchase a motorbike to carry fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to carry fish to sell.

loans.name: Fadhila

texts.en:
Fadhila is a member of the Manazi borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 27 year old woman, She is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 11 and 7 years old.

Fadhila has owned a food business selling chips for 5 years. She works 11 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately  150,000 Tanzanian shillings.


This is Fadhila`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy cooking oil,potatoes for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this  loan, Fadhila hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, potatoes

loans.name: Ayele

texts.fr: Madame Ayélé est une revendeuse ambulante de pagnes de différentes catégories dans le quartier d’Atiégou à Lomé. Elle est mariée à un enseignant d’une école primaire et privée ; le couple a 04 enfants à leur charge. C’est pour soutenir financièrement son mari dans l’éducation scolaire de leurs enfants que cette dame a pris la décision en 2004 de se lancer dans la vente de pagnes. Elle vend le plus souvent de maison en maison ; aujourd’hui elle dispose d’une clientèle non négligeable. Pour renouveler son stock de pagnes, elle sollicite un prêt de WAGES pour acheter au Grand Marché de Lomé 20 pagnes Phoenix, 25 pagnes Sosso et 15 pagnes Hitarget.
texts.en:
Ms. Ayélé is an itinerant retailer of different categories of pagnes (colorful West African cloth) in the Atiégou district in Lomé.  She is married to a teacher at a private primary school;  the couple has four children to support.  Supporting her husband financially to educate their children is why this lady decided to embark upon selling pagnes in 2004.  Usually she sells by going from house to house; today she has a customer base that is not insignificant.  To renew her stock of pagnes, she's requesting a WAGES loan to go to the Grand Market in Lomé to buy several lengths of pagnes:  20 lengths of Phoenix brand , 25 of Sosso, and 15 of Hitarget.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy traditional cloth

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Mich Suon Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
A village bank loan which consists of eighteen people is located in Sdau Aem village in Takeo province and all the members will use the loan in different purposes. Mrs. Mich S. is the village bank president. She is a weaver. Aside from this work, she is a farmer who owns a pL. of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizer and hire laborers to work on the field. In order to solve this problem, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Mrs. Mich S. is a 37-year-old single with two sisters who are employed in a garment factory.        

Five members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: Livingstone's Group

texts.en: K. Livingstone is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a 68 year old man and married with eight children aged 17 – 10 years as he also cares for orphans. Livingstone is a farmer in Luleka / Kkoba village in Lugazi for 20 years and he makes roughly 100,000/= a week from the sale of his agricultural produce to retailers. He is a friendly man and believes that the loans have helped so much in his business enabling him to have quality output. In his farming business, Livingstone needs machines like tractors, insecticides to ensure more quality produce even in the bad seasons. He also wants to start raring animals like cattle, sheep, pigs and goats for increased income. He needs a loan to be able to buy more chicken for his poultry farm and also pay school fees for his children since all of them are still in school.

loans.use: Buying more chicken for farm expansion and to payschool fees for his children.

loans.name: Améyo

texts.fr: Cette dame est mère de 02 enfants. En 1992, elle a été bouleversée dans sa vie privée par le divorce qu’elle a eu avec son mari. Elle a désormais la charge de ses enfants. C’est pour cela qu’elle s’est lancée dans le commerce d’alimentation générale et des produits divers. Actuellement elle a beaucoup de clientèle ; sa boutique se situe dans le Grand Marché de Lomé. Elle a un besoin pressant de renouveler son stock ; pour cela elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 cartons d’eau minérale Voltic, 05 boîtes de Nescafé, 03 boîtes de lait Nestlé, 15 boîtes de savons de lessive BF. Elle souhaite également se lancer dans le commerce des articles scolaires ; c’est pourquoi ce prêt lui permettra aussi d’acheter 15 cahiers de 100 pages, 30 cahiers de 200 pages et bien d’autres articles

loans.use: achat de produits d'alimentation générale et d'articles scolaires

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is a member of the Mnazi middle borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro, She is 49 year old woman. She is widowed and a mother of 6 children. Her children are 30,26,24,22,20,18 years old.

Ester has owned a food business selling potatoes for 7 years. She works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 20,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Ester`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more potatoes.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Ester hopes to save money,pay school fees, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more food for her business

loans.name: Nob

texts.en: Nob V. sells a few items out of her home for a daily profit. At the same time, she is always dealing in rice. She is married to Nhek Srin, age 55, who is a fisherman. They have seven single children, four of whom are employed (two are security guards and two are employed workers). Nob V. will be using her first loan to buy a used car to begin a taxi service. This loan will provide her and her family with additional income and a higher living standard.

loans.use: To buy a used car to begin a taxi service

loans.name: Daryika's Group

texts.en:
Daryika, the leader of this group, is 47 years old. She is divorced and has raised four children. Her eldest son works as a builder while her daughter works in a café. Daryika's other two sons, 11 and 10, are still at school. For last two years Daryika has been earning a living by manufacturing traditional articles for sale, mainly blankets and bedding. Her mother used to make traditional products and taught Daryika the secrets of her profession. Daryika spent $70 USD to purchase thread, needles and fabric to start work. Now, her craft earns her $190 USD a month. She has been able to buy herself a sewing machine and a brand new fridge. Her future plans include marrying her son and helping him buy a new flat. Daryika needs a loan to have cosmetic alterations in her kitchen and also purchase materials and furniture for sewing traditional articles.

Daryika’s partners are Abjapar, Jumagul and Jamiyla. Abjapar, 47, is a father of four children. He works in the market selling milk and eggs. Prior to this occupation he served in the military. After retirement, he decided to take up a trade to keep active. Abjapar needs a loan to buy a cow. He wants to sell sour cream and cottage cheese.

Jumagul, 36, is divorced and is raising a son. In spite of being a servicewoman, she manages to find time to sell writing materials. In this way, she earns a pretty decent income. Jumagul needs a loan to pay for a repair at her house and to purchase more stationery materials to sell.

Jamiyla, 40, is married to a taxi driver and has two children. She works as a jurist in frontier troops. As Jamiyla’s son goes to one of the best private high schools in the country, she needs a loan to pay for his tuition. Her plan is to send her son abroad to pursue his career.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and to view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase materials and furniture for sewing traditional items; to make cosmetic alterations in the kitchen

loans.name: Mrs. Nann Nai Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group has 20 members, all of whom live in the village of Sdau Aem in Takeo province. Mrs. Nann N. is the village bank president who has been selected by the group members. The members will all use their loans for different purposes.

Mrs. Nann N. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice, and she is also a basket maker. Her husband, Mr. Chan Chhun, is a blacksmith. They have three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other attends the local school. The couple work hard but they still do not earn enough income to support their family. Thus, Mrs. Nann N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets to start a breeding business. She will use the rest of the loan to buy pig food to support her new business.

Three members in this group have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. For EoT loans the borrower is not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. They allow borrowers to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food to start a breeding business

loans.name: Agossi Akouvi

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et assure avec son mari l’éducation scolaire de leurs deux enfants. C’est justement pour cette raison qu’elle a décidé en 2003 de vendre des produits d’alimentation générale pour compléter les ressources financières de leur foyer. Actuellement elle a besoin de renouveler son stock ; elle demande d’avoir un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 10 cartons d’OMO, 05 sacs de riz, 03 sacs de gari et 05 bidons d’huile. Elle est très connue dans son quartier Agoè hombi à Lomé.
texts.en:
This woman is married and, with her husband, ensures that their two children are educated.  For this reason only, she decided to sell grocery items in 2003 in order to round out her financial resources at home.  Currently, she needs to renew her inventory;  she's asking WAGES to obtain a loan to buy ten boxes of OMO (a brand of dish detergent), five sacks of rice, three sacks of gari (granulated cassava), and five containers of oil.  She is well-known in her district of Agoè Hombi in Lomé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grocery items

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en: Immaculate K. is 42 years old and married with five children, two of whom are in secondary school. For the past ten years she has run a grocery business in Kayirikiti Local Council in Nyendo Masaka district. Immaculate is requesting a loan to purchase grocery items such as sugar, maize flour, wheat flour and rice. She wants to increase her stock levels of these products so that she can make more profit and meet customer demand. Her business dream is to expand and become successful in her business, but her main desire is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items such as sugar, maize flour, wheat flour and rice

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie V. is 44 years old and the mother of five children. Jasmin, 24, works as a sales lady, as does Adelfa, 22. Daisy, who is 14, is now in her third year of high school. John Carlo, 11, is studying in grade 4 of primary school, while John Vincent is only 4 years old. Rosemarie is married to Rogelio V., 48, who works as a farm laborer. According to Rosemarie, because of poverty her five children have suffered educationally, and some of them did not progress to college level.

When she became a member of Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), Rosemarie hoped that her loan could be used to expand her farming business so that one day it would give her family enough income to cover their expenses. Most importantly she hoped to be able to pay for her children's education. Rosemarie hopes that her children will be able to finish their studies at college and obtain a degree to give them a better future. This is why she never stops finding ways to help her business grow. She is requesting a new loan for use as additional capital for her farming business. She will buy things to improve the farm such as fertilizers, insecticides, binhi or rice seed, and also use the loan to pay the laborers.

Rosemarie’s one hope and goal in life is to alleviate her family's poverty.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, insecticides, binhi or rice seed, and pay farm laborers

loans.name: Sam's Group

texts.en: There are two low-income people show in the picture above. One of these people, Sam T., 44 years old, is looking for a loan to buy a used-motor in order to make her family’s transportation easier. She and her husband are Khmer music players. They are also hired by neighbors to play the music for their wedding parties. This couple has blessed with eight children; two of their children go with them to play music. The other one who is jointly taking this loan; Mrs. Khat H., age 65, is a vegetable seller, who asking for a loan to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To buy a used-motor in order to make her family’s transportation easier

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a member of the KDC borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 35 year old woman, She is married and a mother of 2 children. her children are 10, 8 years old. She also cares for other 2 dependent.

Rose has owed a food business selling banana for 8 years. She works 6 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 50,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Rose`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more banana for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Rose hopes to save more moeny and expand her business.
