loans.use: To buy more banana

loans.name: Aventino

texts.en: M. Aventino is 42 years old and married with six children, one of whom is still at school. For the past ten years Aventino has operated a spare parts retail business, and has sold stoves, pressure lamps and bicycle spare parts, among others. He will use his loan to purchase more spare parts for motorcycles, cars, bicycles, and so forth. His dream is to set up a large spare parts shop so that he can become a leading competitor in the Masaka market, selling in both retail and wholesale. Moreover, he hopes to be able to educate his child.

loans.use: To purchase more spare parts for motorcycles, cars, bicycles, etc.

loans.name: Adjo

texts.fr: Cette dame vend uniquement des objets en plastique en bordure d’une grande ruelle du quartier Forever à Lomé. Elle est mariée à un cuisinier, et le couple a 05 enfants à sa charge. Malheureusement l’hôtel dans lequel travaillait le mari a été fermé ; le mari ayant perdu son emploi, cette dame a pris la décision en 1999 de vendre des objets plastiques pour compenser la perte financière dans le foyer. Elle se rend au Ghana pour faire ses provisions. Actuellement elle a une grande clientèle, ce qui fait qu’elle réalise de bonnes affaires. Elle est dans le besoin de renouveler son stock ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 50 gobelets en plastique, 50 seaux en plastique, 50 assiettes en plastique et 100 paniers en plastique. Elle compte sur sa longue expérience pour vite rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
This lady sells only plastic ware along a big alley in the Forever District in Lomé.  She is married to a cook, and the couple have five children to support.  Unfortunately, the hotel where her husband used to work was closed.  With her husband out of a job, this lady decided in 1999 to sell plastic ware out of her house in order to make up for the financial loss.  She goes to Ghana to stock up.  Currently she has a large customer base, which means business is good.  She needs to renew her stock;  this is why she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy 50 plastic drinking cups, 50 plastic buckets, 50 plastic plates, and 100 plastic baskets.  She's counting on her lengthy experience to repay the loan quickly.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plastic items

loans.name: Taalaikul's Group

texts.en: Thirty-three year old Taailaikul, the leader of this group, is the mother of two kids. Her eldest son, 8, goes to school and the little daughter is just four. Currently Taailajkul does not work but stays at home, as she has to look after her little daughter. As for Taailaikul’s spouse, for the last four years he has been trading in spares. He purchases cars that have been in an accident and dismantles them into spare parts for sale. He used to work as a salesman in a spare parts shop. About a year ago his parents sold their livestock, fetching $800, and bought him a container. Now, he sells spares from his own container. Not having to pay for leasing a container, has let him save enough money to buy a car. His monthly income is around $470. Taailaikul and her husband need a loan to purchase broken down cars, for the resale of spare parts. They want to increase their turnover. As for Taailaikul, she intends to work as a seamstress in the capital. These are Taailaikul’s partners: Bubuajar, Nurbubu, Jumagul and Altyn. Bubuajar, 57, is engaged in raising and breeding livestock. Besides being a farmer’s wife and having brought up three children, she has been working as a doctor’s assistant at the hospital. She needs a loan to buy a milk cow. Nurbubu, 48, has raised six children. Together with her husband she is engaged in cattle breeding. In summer, after sending cattle to pasture, she and her husband grow and process agricultural produce. She needs a loan to buy a cow to sell its milk. Jumagul, 47, is engaged in raising livestock. She started this activity twenty years ago when her parents-in-law gave her and her husband some cattle as a gift. It brings them a stable income of $120. Jumagul needs a loan to purchase a milk cow for breeding. Altyn, 59, is a farmer’s wife and is the mother of six children. To make a living she sells foodstuffs. She has her own shop and makes $95 a month. She needs a loan to purchase more goods and to finish building a summer pub. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase broken down cars for the resale of spare parts

loans.name: Eya

texts.fr: Cette dame a pris la décision en 1998 de vendre à la fois des produits d’alimentation générale , elle y a associé après la vente des produits génériques pour aider financièrement son mari conducteur de taxi à subvenir aux besoins de leurs 04 enfants. Elle exerce cette activité en bordure d’un boulevard très fréquenté dans le quartier de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Actuellement elle a besoin de lancer une nouvelle commande de certains produits manquants ; c’est pourquoi elle sollicite un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 10 boîtes de paracétamol, 15 boîtes d’aspirine, 02 emballages de papiers hyégéniques, 10 boîtes de sardines et 15 cartons de savons de toilettes de différentes sortes. Cette femme a tissé au fil du temps un réseau de clients qui lui ont toujours été fidèles. Elle compte sur ce réseau commercial pour vite rembourser son crédit.
texts.en:
In 1998, this lady decided to sell grocery items.  She has included with it the sale of generic pharmaceutical products to help her taxi-driver husband financially in providing for their four children.  She has been operating this business along a very busy boulevard in the Hédzranawoé district in Lomé.  Currently, she needs to initiate a new order of certain products that are in short supply; this is why she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy 10 boxes of paracétamol, 15 boxes of aspirin, 2 packets of toilet paper, 10 cans of sardines, and 15 boxes of bath soaps of different types.  As time went on, this woman wove a network of customers, who have always been loyal to her.  She is counting on this commercial network to repaid her loan quickly.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grocery items and pharmaceuticals

loans.name: Alima

texts.fr: Cette dame a un grand étalage de vente des produits d’alimentation générale dans le Marché de Hédzranamoé à Lomé. Elle est mariée et est mère de 05 enfants. Elle est mariée à un mécanicien. En 2000, l’atelier de réparation du mari a connu des difficultés financière, ce qui a poussé cette dame à se lancer dans la vente des produits d’alimentation générale. Avec cette activité, elle finance les études universitaires de 02 enfants et 02 filles domestiques qui l’aident au marché de Hédzranamoé. Elle a besoin de renouveler  quelques articles en ce moment ; c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 01 carton de mayonnaise, 12 cartons de tomates, 05 cartons de sardines, 05 paniers de piments, 02 sacs d’haricot ; le reste du montant servira à couvrir les frais de transport.

loans.use: achat de produits d'alimentation générale

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a member of the Sokoni borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 48  year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 20,18,15 years old.

Salome has owned a clothing business for 9 years, she works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Salome`s first loan from BRAC_ Tanzania. She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Salome hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Tatyana's Group

texts.en: The leader of this group, Tatyana, a twenty-nine-year-old woman, sells flowers to earn a living. Her husband is an operator in a beer-selling company. They have two children: a daughter and a son who are eleven and six years old respectively. It is due to her caring husband that Tatyana was able to start her own business. The point is that, four month ago, her husband took a risk in investing his savings, around $240, in taking a florist’s shop on a lease. The expense was worth it as now, Tatyana is able to independently earn her own money. Her husband still helps her transporting the flowers. After running her shop for some months, Tatyana has a desire to make her shop more attractive and fashionable. She has gained some experience and has the vision of improving the interior of her shop. She sees that she will have to obtain a loan to furnish the shop: buy shelves and purchase more kinds of flowers. She also needs this loan to provide clothes for her children for the new academic year. Tatyana’s dreams are to buy her own real estate, increase the turnover of her shop, and buy a hothouse. Here are Tatyana’s partners: Elena, Antonina and one more Elena Elena, a twenty-eight-year-old housewife, has two children. She is occupied with breeding rabbits and this activity lets her have a constant supply of meat at home. She needs a loan to buy two calves to raise and resell. Antonina, 28, is divorced and has a nine-year-old son. To provide for her small family, Antonina works as an operator in a salon containing playing machines. She urgently needs a loan for treatment of her mother, as her mother has stomach cancer. The second Elena, 28, together with her husband, sells detergents and foodstuffs. They have one son. She started this business four years ago after her marriage, since her husband had already been engaged in trade at the market. Elena needs a loan to purchase shelves for her container. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy shelves and more kinds of flowers, and to buy school clothes for her children

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a member of the Mnazi borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 42 years old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 19, 16,and 13 years old.

Lucy has owed a clothing business selling sweaters for 14 years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 30,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Lucy`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh  in order to buy more sweaters for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the us of this loan, Lucy hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more sweaters

loans.name: Abduzabi

texts.en:
A. Abduzabi is 50 years old. He is married with two children. Since he was young he has been in the business of raising and selling cattle which is why he has a lot of experience. It is necessary to point out that Abduzabi has been able to succeed thanks to the support provided by IMON International. This support has been in the form of a loan which he has used to purchase and raise young bulls in their locality. Today Abduzabi has once again come to IMON International for a loan which will allow him to purchase young bulls to raise and sell. It is his biggest dream to improve the conditions of his business in order to then improve the conditions of his family.   
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the young cattle

loans.name: Andrew's Group

texts.en:
Andrew K. is the leader of his lending group in Jinja. He is 35 years old and married with two children, aged 6 years and 18 months. He has had a business running a computer café on Kutch Road in Jinja for one and a half years from which he makes 180,000 Ugandan shillings as weekly profits. In addition to providing Internet services, he offers photocopying, scanning and training services, hence making more profits. When Andrew was first employed, it was in this business. That is when he got the idea of starting his own business and it’s working for him. 

He needs a loan to help buy a photocopying machine for his business since this will continue to diversify the range of services he offers. He has a goal of expanding his business by buying more computers and building his family house and owning a farm. He is a hardworking and friendly man, which helps attract more customers to his business.

loans.use: Buying a photocopying machine for his business

loans.name: Damen

texts.en:
Damen was born around 1977 in Nablus, a city of Palestine. He is married and is the father of three children.

Damen is a photographer and has made it his primary business. Photography brings in the revenues that helps him earn his living.

However, Damen has need of more funding than he currently has for equipping his photo lab. His aim is to offer a better range of services to his customers and to make more income, thus enabling him to better provide for his family.

loans.use: To buy equipment for his photo lab

loans.name: Zainabkhon

texts.en:
S. Zainabkhon, a 47-year-old woman, is married with two children. Zainabkhon has a tailoring shop. Her business is sewing national women's dresses. Her workmanship is very good and, having been in this business for over 30 years, she has a good eye for design. She is very organized and has a good head for business. Zainabkhon started out with only one sewing machine, and now she has expanded her tailoring shop and has more than 20 assistants. With her loan, Zainabkhon will buy additional sewing machines in order to expand her shop. Given her spirit, she will surely succeed!

loans.use: To purchase sewing machines

loans.name: Faiziddin

texts.en:
Faiziddin together with her family has a small business of selling construction supplies in their store which were expanded lately. Their store is filled with attractive, reasonably priced items that appeal to many customers who are looking to construct or build something like office, house and etc. Faiziddin has been in business for about 6 years. He likes what he sells and has developed a stable enterprise. Currently Faiziddin has requested a loan to help purchase a new supply of items to sell.

loans.use: Purchasing new supplies of items to sell

loans.name: Help Yourself #3 Group

texts.en:
Augustine is a 25-year-old widow with two small children, ages 2 months and 2 years old. She also takes care of an orphan. Augustine’s business is dry meat, which she buys wholesale and sells in a temporary market stall alongside approximately 100 other vendors of various trades. She is successful because her customers like her personality and customer service. Augustine has completed the 11th grade but was forced to drop out before graduation. She lives in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa County – the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Augustine's dream is to grow her business until she can build a permanent shop. With the profits from her business, Augustine dreams of raising her family well and sending all her children to school, which she was unable to complete.

"Help Yourself #3" is a group of five borrowers, led by Augustine H., living in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia.

loans.use: To buy one carton of meat

loans.name: Thank God #1 Group

texts.en:
Kpana, a 35-year-old woman, is married with five children between the ages of 5 and 18. She also cares for one child orphaned in the war. Kpana’s business is making clothes for the farming community. She sells in a temporary market stall alongside approximately 100 other vendors of various trades.  She has been running her business for three years. She is illiterate because, although she wanted to attend school, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide. Kpana lives in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa county – the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Kpana's dream is to grow her business until she can build a permanent tailor's shop. She is taking out this loan to buy sewing materials, thread and cloth. With the profits from her business, Kpana dreams of building a permanent house and sending her children to school (which she was denied).

"Thank God #1" is a group of five borrowers, led by Kpana J., living in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia.

loans.use: To purchase sewing material, thread and cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sodabi, a local beverage

loans.name: Yawavi

texts.fr: Cette dame vend uniquement des chaussures pour dame dans le Marché de Hédzranamoé à Lomé. Elle vend à la fois des sandalettes, des chaussures de sortie, des chaussures plates et différentes autres catégories de chaussures. Elle n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Ce commerce lui permet surtout de subvenir à ses propres besoins. Elle s’approvisionne le plus souvent dans le Grand Marché de Lomé ; des vendeuses ambulantes viennent en tout temps chez elle pour s’approvisionner. Pour renouveler son stock en baisse ces temps-ci, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour commander 12 cartons de sandalettes, 15 cartons de chaussures de sortie et d’autres types de chaussures.
texts.en:
This lady sells only women's shoes at the Hédzranamoé Market of Lomé. All together, she sells sandalettes (flip flops), dress shoes, flats, and other types of shoes. She is not married and has no children to support. This business allows her above all to support herself. She usually stocks up at the Grand Market of Lomé; itinerant sales women come to her at any time to stock up. To renew her recently diminished inventory, she's requesting a WAGES loan to order 12 boxes of sandalettes, 15 boxes of dress shoes, and other types of footwear.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shoes

loans.name: One United Club Group

texts.en:
Sangai, a 26-year-old woman living in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa county, Liberia, is married with two children, ages 9 months and 5 years old. Her eldest is not in school. Sangai’s business is retail clothing, including jeans, T-shirts and sandals, which she imports from nearby Guinea. She sells to the farming community from a temporary market stall alongside approximately 100 other vendors of various trades. She has been running her business for three years now. Sangai is illiterate because, although she wanted to attend school, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide.  

Sangai's dream is to grow her business so she can soon have a much bigger stall and ultimately build a permanent clothing shop. After recovering from a two month illness, she is taking out this loan to buy inventory in larger quantities. With the profits from her business, Sangai dreams of building a permanent house and sending her children to school, which she was denied.

One United Club is a group of five borrowers, led by Sangai B., living in Kolahu, Lofa county – the breadbasket of Liberia.

loans.use: To increase inventory of jeans and T-shirts

loans.name: Djamshed

texts.en:
K. Djamshed runs a café cooking different kinds of meals. He is a 30-year-old man, married with four children. Being a very good and experienced cook, Djamshed has managed to make his business successful. The income from the business is used to improve the living conditions of his family. He also dreams of being able to educate his children in the institutes and universities.

Djamshed is planning to make major renovations to the café and to expand it to attract more new clients and keep the old ones. For this, he requests a loan of $2000 US. Djamshed thanks all for the support and promises to be precise in loan payments.

loans.use: Major renovations to a café

loans.name: Ergash

texts.en:
K. Ergash, a 44-year-old man, is married with seven children. Ergash is a farmer. He plants watermelon, corn, wheat, rice and pumpkins. He comes from a farming family and he does very well financially because he takes good care of his land. His wife (in the photo) is his biggest supporter. She helps him in any way she can and takes good care of him and the house. With this loan, he would like to expand his irrigation system which is fundamental when it comes to farming. The loan will greatly improve Ergash’s income and his family's living standards.

loans.use: To purchase seed, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: United Family Group

texts.en:
Varnie is a 41-year-old man living in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa county, Liberia. Varnie’s business is selling food items retail, including palm oil, meat, etc., which he buys wholesale locally and in neighboring Guinea.  He sells to the farming community from his temporary market stall alongside approximately 100 other vendors of various trades.  He has been running his business for four years. 

Varnie is married with two children, ages 2 and 7. He is also taking care of two children orphaned in the war. His eldest is in first grade. Varnie is a high school graduate. 

Varnie is taking out a loan to increase his inventory sufficiently so that he can serve more customers.  With the profits, he dreams of first having a larger market stall and ultimately building a more permanent shop. He is investing in the future of his children, especially their schooling, which he was fortunate to complete. 

United Family is a group of 5 borrowers, led by Varnie N., living in Kolahu, Lofa County – the breadbasket of Liberia.

loans.use: To buy palm oil and meat

loans.name: Nalwagee Group

texts.en:
Comfort is a 35-year-old woman living in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa County, Liberia. Comfort’s business is retail beverages, including water, juice, soft drinks and beer, which she buys locally and also imports from nearby Guinea. She sell to the farming community from her temporary market stall in the Kolahu main market alongside approximately 100 other vendors of various trades. She has been running her business for three years.  

Comfort is married with two children, ages 2 and 6. She is also taking care of one child orphaned in the war. Her eldest is in kindergarten. She was forced to drop out of elementary school because, although she enjoyed it, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. 

Comfort’s dream is to grow her business so that she can soon have a much bigger stall. She says her business is successful because of the way she treats her customers. She is taking out a loan to buy inventory in larger quantities to meet demand. With the profits from her business, Comfort dreams of sending her children to school, which she was denied.

Nalwagee is a group of five borrowers led by Comfort B., living in Kolahu, Lofa County – the breadbasket of Liberia.

loans.use: To increase inventory of water,  juice and soft drinks

loans.name: Abdusattor

texts.en: M. Abdusattor is 52 years old, married, and has six children. He grows watermelons, pumpkins, corn, cucumbers and tomatoes and sells them in the market for income. He has been working in this kind of business for almost seven years and has gained much experience. Abdusattor has a large family considering that he has six children. With his large family, he works almost every day to generate revenues to support his family's living. Because of his family relying on his yield, Abdusattor needs a loan to purchase necessary supplies for his current harvest. In that way he will be able to earn enough money to support his family. Abdusattor has gained a reputation for responsibility with his financial obligations and for keeping his word. We are happy to have another opportunity to assist him with the operation of his business. loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Djikiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djikiya est constitué de 6 femmes mariées (trois sont polygames deux monogames et une célibataire)   ayant en moyenne  32 ans, 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dont le but  est de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de  pagnes wax, de céréales  et de boissons.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,  25 pièces de pagnes wax, 15 sacs de 100 kg de céréales et  30 casiers de boissons. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont vendues aux marchés, de façon ambulante dans les quartiers, dans la famille ou sur commande, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19.000 FCFA dont une partie sera investie dans les activités et l’autre partie en épargne.
Certaines femmes du groupe Djikiya ambitionnent agrandir et diversifier leurs activités et participer à l’épanouissement de leur famille.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers.

loans.name: One Word Business #3 Group

texts.en:
One Word Business #3 is a group of five borrowers living in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia and led by Bandu J..

Bandu is 35 years old and is single, with two children aged 5-8. Her eldest is in the 3rd grade. She was unable to attend school because, although she enjoyed it, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide, and therefore school was considered unnecessary. Bandu lives in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Bandu’s business is dry meat, which she buys wholesale, prepares, and sells in a temporary market stall alongside approximately one hundred other vendors of various trades. She is successful because her customers like her personality and the way she prepares the meat.

Bandu’s dream is to grow her business so she can one day get married and build a permanent shop. With the profits from her business, she dreams of raising her family well and sending all her children to school which she was unable to attend herself.

loans.use: To purchase a carton of meat

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: faire le labour et acheter des engrais

loans.name: Sidiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sidiya, constitué de  4 femmes mariées (deux polygames et deux monogames)   ayant  une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, 2 enfants, vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Médine un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dont le but  est de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de  condiments,  de bois de chauffe et de boissons.  
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 15 colis de condiments , 15 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe et 20 casiers de boissons. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché, de façon ambulante dans les quartiers, dans la famille ou sur commande et au marché de Médine, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19.000 FCFA dont une partie sera investie dans les activités et l’autre partie en épargne.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers.

loans.name: Kitoboi #2 Group

texts.en:
Kitoboi #2 is a group of five borrowers, led by Molay Z., living in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia.

Molay is 45 years old and married with three children, aged 8-23. Her middle child is in the 8th grade but the oldest didn’t get to attend school because of the war. Molay was unable to attend school because, although she enjoyed it, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide, and therefore school was considered unnecessary. Molay lives in remote Kolahu City in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia.

Molay’s business is dry goods, including Maggi cubes (a soup product), spices, matches, palm oil, etc., which she buys wholesale and sells in a temporary market stall alongside approximately one hundred other vendors of various trades. She has run her business for four years and is successful because her customers like her personality and her work ethic.

Molay’s dream is to grow her business so that she can one day have a bigger table in the market. With the profits from her business she dreams of raising her family well and sending her youngest children to school which she was unable to attend.

loans.use: To purchase spices, palm oil, and Maggi cubes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cloth for resale

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en:
Claudia is a member of the Majengo borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 46 year old woman, she is widowed and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 28, 24, 22 years old.

Claudia has owned a grocery business selling drinks for 8 years, she works 16 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Claudia`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more drinks.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Claudia hopes to save money, pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more drinkslike beer and soda

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other agricultural inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Culture de la patate douce

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is 35 years old and a father of four who lives and operates his food kiosk business in Mukuru, Nairobi, Kenya. Patrick has requested a loan of Ksh 60,000 in order to add to his stock of maize flour, wheat flour, oil and beans. He has been in this business for the last five years. Patrick hopes to own a hotel in Nairobi one day and to make a good foundation for his family. He describes himself as diligent and faithful. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add to his stock

loans.name: Amidou

texts.fr:
Monsieur   Amidou S. a 41 ans, marié et père de six  enfants. Il vit avec sa famille à Noumousso, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo (dans la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur S. est dans le domaine du commerce il ya six ans. Aujourd’hui il s’est frayé un chemin et dispose d’une boutique où il vend divers articles de consommation en plus des céréales. Expérimenté et crédible il mène son activité avec discernement  et sert sa clientèle qui ne cesse de croitre. 
Afin de satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, il collabore avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il  est à son cinquième prêt  individuel , tous les précédents se sont bien dénoué. 
Avec ce  prêt, il compte acheter,  30sacs de 50kg de riz, 5 sacs de 100kg de sorgho et 10 sacs de 50kg de sucre. Il s'approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes à Kadiolo avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et surtout de fonctionnaires.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Amidou S. is 41 years old, married, and the father of six children.  He lives with his family in Noumousso, a district in the city of Kadiolo (in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Mr. S. has been in commerce for six years.  He cleared his own way and now has a shop where he sells various consumer goods, in addition grains.  Experienced and credible, he runs his business with wisdom and serves his ever-growing customer base.  To satisfy his more and more numerous customers, he is collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  He is on his fifth individual loan.  All his previous ones were settled.  With the present loan, he intends to buy thirty 50-kg sacks of rice, five 100-kg sacks of sorghum, and ten 50-kg sacks of sugar.  He stocks up in Kadiolo and then sells these goods retail to customers composed men, women, and particularly civil servants. With this loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase his business fund, to help with family expenses, to cover the loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods:  sugar, sorghum, and rice

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Siaka K. a 36 ans, marié et père de trois enfants, il vit avec sa famille à Noumousso, un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo (dans la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  K. est dans le domaine du commerce il ya plus d’une année maintenant. Aujourd’hui il commence à se faire un chemin et dispose d’une boutique où il vend des articles tels  le ciment et les céréales.  Très apprécié et sollicité sa clientèle  ne cesse de croitre. 
Alors pour satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, il collabore avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il  est à son troisième prêt  individuel  après avoir correctement remboursés les deux précédents.
Avec ce  prêt, il compte acheter,  50 sacs de ciment et 4 sacs de 100kg de maïs. Il s’approvisionne auprès des commerçants grossistes  à Kadiolo ville et environnants avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et surtout de forains.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 65.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers.

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en:
Youssef is a 44-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children.

Youssef has owned a shoe shop since 1994. He has requested a loan of 3,000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase the new shoe winter collection. This is the first time that Youssef has requested a loan.

Youssef is special in his work because he offers good quality and choice of shoes. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Youssef first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding by opening another shoe shop.

loans.use: To purchase the new shoe winter collection

loans.name: Veneranda

texts.en:
Veneranda is a member of the KDC borrower group in Kiboriloni, Kilimanjaro. She is 35  year old woman. she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 13,8, and 6 years old .

Veneranda has own a shop business selling commodities like rice,wheat, cooking oil for  1 year. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Veneranda`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, cooking oil etc.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Veneranda hopes to save more money and expand her family

loans.use: To buy morerice, wheat,cokking oil

loans.name: Hashem

texts.en:
Hashem is a 35-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon.

Hashem has owned a clothing shop since 1999. He sells, T-shirts, pajamas, sportswear, etc. He has requested a loan of 2,000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise since the winter season is coming. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

Hashem is special in his work because he offers a big variety of clothes. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because of his experience since he used to work with his father. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal clothing
